At the time of his death, his estate was worth an estimated $780,000 in 1799, equivalent to $13.72 million in 2022.[359] Washington\'s peak net worth was $587 million, including 300 slaves.[360] Washington held title to more than 65,000 acres of land in 37 different locations.[72]\nIn 1830, a disgruntled ex-employee of the estate attempted to steal what he thought was Washington\'s skull, prompting the construction of a more secure vault.[361] In his will, Washington had left instructions for the construction of a new vault as the old family vault was crumbling and needed repair even before his death.[352] A new vault was constructed at Mount Vernon the following year to receive the remains of George and Martha and other relatives.[362]\nIn 1832, a joint Congressional committee debated moving his body from Mount Vernon to a crypt in the Capitol. The crypt had been built by architect Charles Bulfinch in the 1820s during the reconstruction of the burned-out capital, after the Burning of Washington by the British during the War of 1812. Southern opposition was intense, antagonized by an ever-growing rift between North and South; many were concerned that Washington\'s remains could end up on "a shore foreign to his native soil" if the country became divided, and Washington\'s remains stayed in Mount Vernon.[363]\nOn October 7, 1837, Washington\'s remains, still in the original lead coffin, were placed within a marble sarcophagus designed by William Strickland and constructed by John Struthers.[364] The sarcophagus was sealed and encased with planks, and an outer vault was constructed around it.[365] The outer vault has the sarcophagi of both George and Martha Washington; the inner vault has the remains of other Washington family members and relatives.[362]\nWashington was somewhat reserved in personality, but was known for having a strong presence. He made speeches and announcements when required, but he was not a noted orator or debater.[366] He was taller than most of his contemporaries;[367] accounts of his height vary from 6 ft (1.83 m) to 6 ft 3.5 in (1.92 m) tall,[64][368] he weighed between 210220 pounds (95100 kg) as an adult,[369] and was known for his great strength.[370]\nHe had grey-blue eyes and long reddish-brown hair. He did not wear a powdered wig; instead he wore his hair curled, powdered, and tied in a queue in the fashion of the day.[371][372]\nWashington frequently suffered from severe tooth decay and ultimately lost all his teeth but one. He had several sets of false teeth during his presidency. Contrary to common lore, these were not made of wood, but of metal, ivory, bone, animal teeth, and human teeth possibly obtained from slaves.[373] These dental problems left him in constant pain, which he treated with laudanum.[374]\nWashington was a talented equestrian, with Thomas Jefferson describing him as "the best horseman of his age".[375] He collected thoroughbreds at Mount Vernon, his two favorite horses being Blueskin and Nelson.[376] He enjoyed hunting foxes, deer, ducks, and other game.[377] He was an excellent dancer and frequently attended the theater. He drank alcohol in moderation but was morally opposed to excessive drinking, smoking tobacco, gambling, and profanity.[378]\nWashington was descended from Anglican minister Lawrence Washington, whose troubles with the Church of England may have prompted his heirs to emigrate to America.[379] He was baptized as an infant in April 1732 and became a devoted member of the Anglican Church.[380] He served more than 20 years as a vestryman and churchwarden at Fairfax Parish and Truco Parish in Virginia.[381] He privately prayed and read the Bible daily, and publicly encouraged people and the nation to pray.[382] He may have taken communion on a regular basis prior to the Revolution, but he did not do so following the war.[383]\nWashington believed in a "wise, inscrutable, and irresistible" Creator God who was active in the Universe, contrary to deistic thought.[379] He referred to God in Enlightenment terms, including Providence, the Creator, or the Almighty, and the Divine Author or Supreme Being.[384] He believed in a divine power who watched over battlefields, was involved in the outcome of war, protected his life, and was involved in American politics and specifically the creation of the United States.[n][386] Historian Ron Chernow has argued that Washington avoided evangelistic Christianity or hellfire-and-brimstone speech along with communion or anything inclined to "flaunt his religiosity", saying that he "never used his religion as a device for partisan purposes or in official undertakings".[387] No mention of Jesus Christ appears in his private correspondence, and such references are rare in his public writings.[388] At the same time, Washington frequently quoted from the Bible or paraphrased it, and often referred to the Anglican Book of Common Prayer.[389]\nWashington emphasized religious toleration in a nation with numerous denominations and religions. He publicly attended services of different Christian denominations and prohibited anti-Catholic celebrations in the Army.[390] He engaged workers at Mount Vernon without regard for religious belief or affiliation. While president, he acknowledged major religious sects and gave speeches on religious toleration.[391] He was distinctly rooted in the ideas, values, and modes of thinking of the Enlightenment,[392] but he harbored no contempt of organized Christianity and its clergy, "being no bigot myself to any mode of worship".[392] In 1793, speaking to members of the New Church in Baltimore, Washington said, "We have abundant reason to rejoice that in this Land the light of truth and reason has triumphed over the power of bigotry and superstition."[393]\nFreemasonry was a widely accepted institution in the late 18th century, known for advocating moral teachings.[394] Washington was attracted to the Masons\' dedication to the Enlightenment principles of rationality, reason, and brotherhood. American Masonic lodges did not share the anti-clerical views of the controversial European lodges.[395]\nA Masonic lodge was established in Fredericksburg, Virginia in September 1752, and Washington was initiated two months later at the age of 20 as one of its first Entered Apprentices. Within a year, he progressed through its ranks to become a Master Mason.[396] Washington had high regard for the Masonic Order, but his lodge attendance was sporadic. In 1777, a convention of Virginia lodges asked him to be the Grand Master of the newly established Grand Lodge of Virginia, but he declined due to his commitments leading the Continental Army. After 1782, he frequently corresponded with Masonic lodges and members,[397] and he was listed as Master in the Virginia charter of Alexandria Lodge No. 22 in 1788.[398]\nIn Washington\'s lifetime, slavery was deeply ingrained in the economic and social fabric of the Colony of Virginia, which continued after the Revolution and the establishment of Virginia as a state.[399][400] Slavery was legal in all of the Thirteen Colonies prior to the American Revolution.[401]\nWashington owned and rented enslaved African Americans, and during his lifetime over 577 slaves lived and worked at Mount Vernon.[402][403] He acquired them through inheritance, gaining control of 84 dower slaves upon his marriage to Martha, and purchased at least 71 slaves between 1752 and 1773.[404] From 1786, he rented slaves; at the time of his death he was renting 41.[405][402]\nPrior to the Revolutionary War, Washington\'s view on slavery was the same as most Virginia planters of the time.[406] Beginning in the 1760s, however, Washington gradually grew to oppose it. His first doubts were prompted by his transition from tobacco to grain crops, which left him with a costly surplus of slaves, causing him to question the system\'s economic efficiency.[407] His growing disillusionment with the institution was spurred by the principles of the Revolution and revolutionary friends such as Lafayette and Hamilton.[408] Most historians agree the Revolution was central to the evolution of Washington\'s attitudes on slavery;[409] "After 1783," Kenneth Morgan writes, "... [Washington] began to express inner tensions about the problem of slavery more frequently, though always in private".[410] Regardless, Washington would remain dependent on slave labor to work his farms.[411]\nThe many contemporary reports of slave treatment at Mount Vernon are varied and conflicting.[412] Historian Kenneth Morgan maintains that Washington was frugal on spending for clothes and bedding for his slaves, and only provided them with just enough food, and that he maintained strict control over his slaves, instructing his overseers to keep them working hard from dawn to dusk year-round.[413] In contrast, historian Dorothy Twohig said: "Food, clothing, and housing seem to have been at least adequate".[414]\nWashington faced growing debts involved with the costs of supporting slaves. He held an "engrained sense of racial superiority" towards African Americans but harbored no ill feelings toward them.[415] Some enslaved families worked at different locations on the plantation but were allowed to visit one another on their days off.[416] Washington\'s slaves received two hours off for meals during the workday and were given time off on Sundays and religious holidays.[417][418]\nSome accounts report that Washington opposed flogging but at times sanctioned its use, generally as a last resort, on both men and women slaves.[419] Washington used both reward and punishment to encourage discipline and productivity in his slaves. He tried appealing to an individual\'s sense of pride, gave better blankets and clothing to the "most deserving", and motivated his slaves with cash rewards. He believed "watchfulness and admonition" were better deterrents against transgressions but would punish those who "will not do their duty by fair means". Punishment ranged in severity from demotion back to fieldwork, through whipping and beatings, to permanent separation from friends and family by sale. Historian Ron Chernow maintains that overseers were required to warn slaves before resorting to the lash and required Washington\'s written permission before whipping, though his extended absences did not always permit this.[420]\nDuring his presidency, Washington brought several of his slaves to the federal capital. When the capital moved from New York City to Philadelphia in 1791, the president began rotating his slave household staff periodically between the capital and Mount Vernon. This was done deliberately to circumvent Pennsylvania\'s Slavery Abolition Act, which stated that any slave who lived there for more than six months was automatically freed.[421]\nIn May 1796, Martha\'s personal and favorite slave Ona Judge escaped to Portsmouth, New Hampshire. At Martha\'s behest, Washington attempted to capture Ona, using a Treasury agent, but failed. In February 1797, around the time of his 65th birthday, Washington\'s personal slave Hercules Posey escaped from Mount Vernon to Philadelphia and was never found.[422]\nIn February 1786, Washington took a census of Mount Vernon and recorded 224 slaves.[423] By 1799, the slave population at Mount Vernon totaled 317, including 143 children.[424] Washington owned 124 slaves, leased 40, and held 153 for his wife\'s dower interest.[425][6] Washington supported many slaves who were too young or too old to work, greatly increasing Mount Vernon\'s slave population and causing the plantation to operate at a loss.[426]\nBased on his private papers and on accounts from his contemporaries, Washington slowly developed a cautious sympathy toward abolitionism that eventually ended with his will freeing his long-time valet Billy Lee, and then subsequently freeing the rest of his personally owned slaves outright upon Martha\'s death.[427][428] As president, he remained publicly silent on the topic of slavery, believing it was a nationally divisive issue that could undermine the union.[429]\nDuring the Revolutionary War, Washington\'s views on slavery began to change.[401] In a 1778 letter to Lund Washington, he made clear his desire "to get quit of Negroes" when discussing the exchange of slaves for the land he wanted to buy.[430] The next year, Washington stated his intention not to separate enslaved families as a result of "a change of masters".[431] During the 1780s, Washington privately expressed his support for gradual emancipation.[432] In the 1780s, he gave moral support to a plan proposed by Lafayette to purchase land and free slaves to work on it, but declined to participate in the experiment.[414]\nWashington privately expressed support for emancipation to prominent Methodists Thomas Coke and Francis Asbury in 1785 but declined to sign their petition.[433] In personal correspondence the next year, he made clear his desire to see the institution of slavery ended by a gradual legislative process, a view that correlated with the mainstream antislavery literature published in the 1780s that Washington possessed.[434] He significantly reduced his purchases of slaves after the war but continued to acquire them in small numbers.[435]\nIn 1788, Washington declined a suggestion from a leading French abolitionist, Jacques Brissot, to establish an abolitionist society in Virginia, stating that although he supported the idea, the time was not yet right.[436] Historian Philip D. Morgan wrote that Washington was determined not to risk national unity.[437] Washington never responded to any of the antislavery petitions he received, and the subject was not mentioned in either his last address to Congress or his Farewell Address.[438]\nThe first clear indication that Washington seriously intended to free his slaves appears in a letter written to his secretary, Tobias Lear, in 1794.[439] Washington instructed Lear to find buyers for his land in western Virginia, explaining in a private coda that he was doing so "to liberate a certain species of property which I possess, very repugnantly to my own feelings".[440] The plan, along with others Washington considered in 1795 and 1796, could not be realized because he failed to find buyers for his land, his reluctance to break up slave families, and the refusal of the Custis heirs to help prevent such separations by freeing their dower slaves at the same time.[441]\nOn July 9, 1799, Washington finished making his last will; the longest provision concerned slavery. All his slaves were to be freed after the death of his wife. Washington said he did not free them immediately because his slaves intermarried with his wife\'s dower slaves. He forbade their sale or transportation out of Virginia. The provision also provided that old and young freed people be taken care of indefinitely; younger ones were to be taught to read and write and placed in suitable occupations.[442] Washington emancipated 123 slaves, one of the few large slave-holding Virginians during the Revolutionary Era to do so.[443][444]\nOn January 1, 1801, one year after George Washington\'s death, Martha Washington signed an order to free his slaves. Many of them, having never strayed far from Mount Vernon, were reluctant to leave; others refused to abandon spouses or children still held as dower slaves by the Custis estate and also stayed with or near Martha.[445] Following Washington\'s instructions in his will, funds were used to feed and clothe the young, aged, and infirm slaves until the early 1830s.[446]\nWashington\'s legacy endures as one of the most influential in American history since he served as commander-in-chief of the Continental Army, a hero of the Revolution, and the first president of the United States. Various historians maintain that he also was a dominant factor in America\'s founding.[447] Revolutionary War comrade Henry Lee eulogized him as "First in war, first in peace, and first in the hearts of his countrymen".[448] Lee\'s words became the hallmark by which Washington\'s reputation was impressed upon the American memory, with some biographers regarding him as the great exemplar of republicanism. He set many precedents for the national government and the presidency in particular, and he was called the "Father of His Country" as early as 1778.[o][450][451]\nWashington became an international symbol for liberation and nationalism as the leader of the first successful revolution against a colonial empire. The Federalists made him the symbol of their party, but the Jeffersonians continued to distrust his influence for years and delayed building the Washington Monument.[452] Washington was elected a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences on January 31, 1781.[453]\nIn 1879, Congress proclaimed Washington\'s Birthday to be a federal holiday.[454] Through a congressional joint resolution Public Law 94-479, passed on January 19, 1976, with an effective appointment date of July 4, 1976, he was posthumously appointed to the grade of General of the Armies of the United States during the American Bicentennial. President Gerald Ford stated that Washington would "rank first among all officers of the Army, past and present".[p][456] On March 13, 1978, Washington was militarily promoted to the rank of General of the Armies.[457]\nIn 1809, Mason Locke Weems wrote a hagiographic biography to honor Washington.[458] Historian Ron Chernow maintains that Weems attempted to humanize Washington, making him look less stern, and to inspire "patriotism and morality" and to foster "enduring myths", such as Washington\'s refusal to lie about damaging his father\'s cherry tree.[459][460] Weems\' accounts have never been proven or disproven.[461] Historian John Ferling, however, maintains that Washington remains the only founder and president ever to be referred to as "godlike", and points out that his character has been the most scrutinized by historians.[462] Biographer Douglas Southall Freeman concluded, "The great big thing stamped across that man is character." Expanding on Freeman\'s assessment, historian David Hackett Fischer defined Washington\'s character as "integrity, self-discipline, courage, absolute honesty, resolve, and decision, but also forbearance, decency, and respect for others".[463]\nIn the 21st century, Washington\'s reputation has been critically scrutinized. Along with other Founding Fathers, he has been condemned for holding enslaved people. Though he expressed the desire to see the abolition of slavery come through legislation, he did not initiate or support any initiatives for bringing about its end. This has led to calls from some activists to remove his name from public buildings and his statue from public spaces.[464] Nonetheless, Washington maintains his place among the highest-ranked U.S. Presidents.[465]\nMany places and monuments have been named in honor of Washington, most notably Washington, D.C., the capital of the United States, and the state of Washington, the only U.S. state to be named after a president.[466]\nOn February 21, 1885, the Washington Monument was dedicated. The 555-foot marble obelisk, which stands on the National Mall in Washington, D.C., was built between 18481854 and 18791884 and was the tallest structure in the world between 1884 and 1889.[467]\nWashington appears as one of four U.S. presidents on the Shrine of Democracy, a colossal statue by Gutzon Borglum on Mount Rushmore in South Dakota.[468]\nA number of secondary schools and universities are named in honor of Washington, including George Washington University and Washington University in St. Louis.[469][470]\nWashington appears on contemporary U.S. currency, including the one-dollar bill, the Presidential one-dollar coin and the quarter-dollar coin (the Washington quarter). Washington and Benjamin Franklin appeared on the nation\'s first postage stamps in 1847. Washington has since appeared on many postage issues, more than any other person.[471]\n'
In [23]:
# Task 1.2.1
# en_core_web_md was not working on my machine. I tried finding workarounds but only one I could find was using "en_core_web_sm"
import en_core_web_sm
from collections import Counter

nlp = en_core_web_sm.load()

doc = nlp(content)
labels = [ent.label_ for ent in doc.ents]

Counter(labels)

# Task 1.2.2
import re

num_reg = re.compile('^-?\\d*(\\.\\d+)?$')

tokens = [token.text for token in doc if
          (not nlp.vocab[token.text].is_stop) and 
          (num_reg.match(token.text)is None) and 
          (not nlp.vocab[token.text].is_punct)]

ct = Counter(tokens)
ct.most_common(20)
Out[24]:

# Task 1.2.3

import random

sents = list(doc.sents)

k = random.randint(0, len(sents)-2)
print("random selected k = {}\n".format(k))

selected_sents=[]
for i in range(k, k+3):
    selected_sents.append(sents[i])
    print("sent #{} : {}".format(i, sents[i]))

random selected k = 72

sent #72 : Crawford allotted 23,200 acres (9,400 ha) to Washington; Washington told the veterans that their land was hilly and unsuitable for farming, and he agreed to purchase 20,147 acres (8,153 ha), leaving some feeling they had been duped.[54] He also doubled the size of Mount Vernon to 6,500 acres (2,600 ha) and, by 1775, had increased its slave population by more than a hundred.[55]
As a respected military hero and large landowner, Washington held local offices and was elected to the Virginia provincial legislature, representing Frederick County in the House of Burgesses for seven years beginning in 1758.[55]
sent #73 : He first ran for the seat in 1755 but was soundly beaten by Hugh West.[56][57] When he ran in 1758, Washington plied voters with beer, brandy, and other beverages.
sent #74 : Despite being away serving on the Forbes Expedition, he won the election with roughly 40 percent of the vote, defeating three opponents with the help of local supporters.[58][59]
Early in his legislative career, Washington rarely spoke or even attended legislative sessions.
In [26]:
# Task 1.2.4
pos_lemma = []
for sent in selected_sents:
    for token in sent:
        if not token.is_stop and token.pos_!='PUNCT':
            pos_lemma.append((token.orth_, token.pos, token.lemma))
            
print(pos_lemma)

In [27]:
# Task 1.2.5
ents = []
for sent in selected_sents:
    for ent in sent.ents:
        ents.append((ent.text, ent.label_))
        
print(ents)

Crawford ORG allotted 23,200 acres QUANTITY ( 9,400 CARDINAL ha) to Washington GPE ; Washington GPE told the veterans that their land was hilly and unsuitable for farming, and he agreed to purchase 20,147 acres QUANTITY ( 8,153 CARDINAL ha), leaving some feeling they had been duped.[54] He also doubled the size of Mount Vernon GPE to 6,500 acres QUANTITY ( 2,600 CARDINAL ha) and, by 1775 DATE , had increased its slave population by more than a hundred.[55]
As a respected military hero and large landowner, Washington GPE held local offices and was elected to the Virginia GPE provincial legislature, representing Frederick County GPE in the House of Burgesses ORG for seven years DATE beginning in 1758.[55]

# Task 1.2.7

displacy.render(doc, style="ent")

George Washington PERSON ( February 22, 1732 DATE December 14, 1799 DATE ) was an American NORP military officer, statesman, and Founding Father who served as the first ORDINAL president of the United States GPE from 1789 to 1797 DATE . Appointed by the Second ORDINAL Continental Congress as commander of the Continental Army ORG in June 1775 DATE , Washington GPE led Patriot forces to victory in the American Revolutionary War and then served as president of the Constitutional Convention ORG in 1787 DATE , which drafted and ratified the Constitution of the United States LAW and established the American NORP federal government. Washington GPE has thus been called the "Father of his Country".
Washington GPE 's first ORDINAL public office, from 1749 to 1750 DATE , was as surveyor of Culpeper County GPE in the Colony of Virginia GPE . He subsequently received military training and was assigned command of the Virginia Regiment ORG during the French NORP and Indian War EVENT . He was later elected to the Virginia House of Burgesses ORG and was named a delegate to the Continental Congress ORG in Philadelphia GPE , which appointed him Commander-in-Chief of the Continental Army ORG . Washington GPE led American NORP forces to a decisive victory over the British NORP in the Revolutionary War EVENT , leading the British NORP to sign the Treaty of Paris WORK_OF_ART , which acknowledged the sovereignty and independence of the United States GPE . He resigned his commission in 1783 DATE after the conclusion of the Revolutionary War EVENT .
Washington GPE played an indispensable role in adopting and ratifying the Constitution LAW , which replaced the Articles of Confederation ORG in 1789 DATE . He was then twice elected president by the Electoral College ORG unanimously. As the first ORDINAL U.S. GPE president, Washington GPE implemented a strong, well-financed national government while remaining impartial in a fierce rivalry that emerged between cabinet members Thomas Jefferson PERSON and Alexander Hamilton PERSON . During the French Revolution EVENT , he proclaimed a policy of neutrality while sanctioning the Jay Treaty LAW . He set enduring precedents for the office of president, including use of the title "Mr. President" and the two CARDINAL -term tradition. His 1796 DATE farewell address became a preeminent statement on republicanism in which he wrote about the importance of national unity and the dangers regionalism, partisanship, and foreign influence pose to it.
Washington GPE has been memorialized by monuments, a federal holiday DATE , various media depictions, geographical locations including the national capital, the State of Washington ORG , stamps, and currency. He is ranked among the greatest U.S. GPE presidents. In 1976 DATE , Washington GPE was posthumously promoted to the rank of General of the Armies, the highest rank in the U.S. Army ORG . His legacy is marred, however, by his ownership of slaves and his complicated relationship with slavery, as well as his policy to assimilate Native Americans NORP into the Anglo NORP -American culture and waging war against Native American NORP nations during the Revolutionary Wars EVENT and the Northwest Indian War EVENT .
George Washington PERSON was born on February 22 DATE , 1732,[a] at Popes Creek FAC in Westmoreland County GPE , Virginia.[3] He was the first ORDINAL of six CARDINAL children of Augustine PERSON and Mary Ball Washington.[4 PERSON ] His father was a justice of the peace and a prominent public figure who had four CARDINAL additional children from his first ORDINAL marriage to Jane Butler.[5 PERSON ] The family moved to Little Hunting Creek WORK_OF_ART in 1734 DATE before eventually settling in Ferry Farm ORG near Fredericksburg GPE , Virginia GPE . When Augustine PERSON died in 1743 DATE , Washington GPE inherited Ferry Farm PRODUCT and ten CARDINAL slaves; his older half CARDINAL -brother Lawrence PERSON inherited Little Hunting Creek PERSON and renamed it Mount Vernon.[6][7 LOC ]
Washington GPE did not have the formal education his elder brothers received at Appleby Grammar School ORG in England GPE , but he did attend the Lower Church School ORG in Hartfield GPE . He learned mathematics, trigonometry, and land surveying, and became a talented draftsman and mapmaker. By early adulthood, he was writing with "considerable force" and "precision".[8] As a teenager, to practice his penmanship, Washington GPE compiled over a hundred rules for social interaction styled Rules of Civility and Decent Behaviour ORG in Company and Conversation, copied from an English LANGUAGE translation of a French NORP book of manners.[9 FAC ]
Washington GPE often visited Mount Vernon GPE and Belvoir GPE , the plantation of William Fairfax PERSON , Lawrence PERSON 's father-in-law. Fairfax GPE became Washington GPE 's patron and surrogate father, and Washington GPE spent a month DATE in 1748 DATE with a team surveying Fairfax GPE 's Shenandoah Valley LOC property.[10] The following year DATE , he received a surveyor's license from the College of William & Mary.[b ORG ] Even though Washington GPE had not served the customary apprenticeship, Fairfax GPE appointed him surveyor of Culpeper County GPE , Virginia GPE , where he took his oath of office July 20, 1749 DATE . He subsequently familiarized himself with the frontier region, and though he resigned from the job in 1750 DATE , he continued to do surveys west of the Blue Ridge ORG Mountains.[11] By 1752 DATE , he had bought almost 1,500 acres QUANTITY ( 600 CARDINAL ha) in the Valley LOC and owned 2,315 acres QUANTITY ( 937 CARDINAL ha).[12]
In 1751 DATE , Washington GPE made his only trip abroad when he accompanied Lawrence PERSON to Barbados, hoping the climate would cure his brother's tuberculosis.[13] Washington GPE contracted smallpox during that trip, which left his face slightly scarred.[14] Lawrence PERSON died in 1752 DATE , and Washington GPE leased Mount Vernon LOC from his widow Anne PERSON ; he inherited it outright after her death in 1761.[15 CARDINAL ]
Lawrence Washington's PERSON service as adjutant general of the Virginia GPE militia inspired George PERSON to seek a commission. Virginia GPE 's lieutenant governor, Robert Dinwiddie PERSON , appointed Washington GPE as a major and commander of one CARDINAL of the four CARDINAL militia districts. The British NORP and French NORP were competing for control of the Ohio Valley LOC : the British NORP were constructing forts along the Ohio River LOC , and the French NORP between the Ohio River LOC and Lake Erie.[16 GPE ]
In October 1753 DATE , Dinwiddie ORG appointed Washington GPE as a special envoy. He had sent Washington GPE to demand French NORP forces to vacate land that was claimed by the British NORP . Washington GPE was also appointed to make peace with the Iroquois Confederacy ORG , and to gather further intelligence about the French NORP forces.[17] Washington GPE met with Half-King Tanacharison ORG , and other Iroquois NORP chiefs, at Logstown ORG , and gathered information about the numbers and locations of the French NORP forts, as well as intelligence concerning individuals taken prisoner by the French NORP . Washington GPE was nicknamed Conotocaurius ORG by Tanacharison ORG . The name, meaning "devourer of villages", had been given to his great-grandfather John Washington PERSON in the late 17th century DATE by the Susquehannock.[18]
Washington GPE 's party reached the Ohio River ORG in November 1753 DATE , and was intercepted by a French NORP patrol. The party was escorted to Fort Le Boeuf FAC , where Washington GPE was received in a friendly manner. He delivered the British NORP demand to vacate to the French NORP commander Saint-Pierre PERSON , but the French NORP refused to leave. Saint-Pierre PERSON gave Washington GPE his official answer after a few days' DATE delay, as well as food and winter DATE clothing for his party's journey back to Virginia.[19] Washington GPE completed the precarious mission in 77 days DATE , in difficult winter DATE conditions, achieving a measure of distinction when his report was published in Virginia GPE and London.[20]
In February 1754 DATE , Dinwiddie ORG promoted Washington GPE to lieutenant colonel and second ORDINAL -in-command of the 300 CARDINAL -strong Virginia Regiment ORG , with orders to confront French NORP forces at the Forks LOC of the Ohio.[21] Washington GPE set out with half CARDINAL the regiment in April DATE and soon learned a French NORP force of 1,000 CARDINAL had begun construction of Fort Duquesne LOC there. In May DATE , having set up a defensive position at Great Meadows ORG , he learned that the French NORP had made camp seven miles QUANTITY ( 11 km QUANTITY ) away; he decided to take the offensive.[22]
The French NORP detachment proved to be only about 50 CARDINAL men, so Washington GPE advanced on May 28 DATE with a small force of Virginians NORP and Indian NORP allies to ambush them.[c][24] During the ambush, French NORP forces were killed outright with muskets and hatchets, including French NORP commander Joseph Coulon de Jumonville PERSON , who had been carrying a diplomatic message for the British NORP . The French NORP later found their countrymen dead and scalped and blamed Washington GPE , who had retreated to Fort GPE Necessity.[25]
The full Virginia Regiment ORG joined Washington GPE at Fort Necessity FAC the following month DATE with news that he had been promoted to command of the regiment and colonel upon the regimental commander's death. The regiment was reinforced by an independent company of a hundred CARDINAL South Carolinians NORP led by Captain James Mackay PERSON ; his royal commission outranked Washington GPE 's and a conflict of command ensued. On July 3 DATE , a French NORP force attacked with 900 men, and the ensuing battle ended in Washington GPE 's surrender.[26] He signed a surrender document in which he unwittingly took responsibility for "assassinating" Jumonville GPE , later blaming the translator for not properly translating it.[27]
In the aftermath, Colonel James Innes PERSON took command of intercolonial forces, the Virginia Regiment ORG was divided, and Washington GPE was offered a captaincy in one CARDINAL of the newly formed regiments. He refused, however, as it would have been a demotion and instead resigned his commission.[28] The "Jumonville affair" became the incident which ignited the French NORP and Indian War EVENT , later to become part of the Seven Years' DATE War.[29][30]
In 1755 DATE , Washington GPE served voluntarily as an aide to General Edward Braddock PERSON , who led a British NORP expedition to expel the French NORP from Fort Duquesne LOC and the Ohio GPE Country.[31] On Washington GPE 's recommendation, Braddock PERSON split the army into one main column and a lightly equipped "flying column".[32] Suffering from severe dysentery, Washington GPE was left behind, and when he rejoined Braddock PERSON at Monongahela GPE the French NORP and their Indian NORP allies ambushed the divided army. Two-thirds CARDINAL of the British NORP force became casualties, including the mortally wounded Braddock ORG . Under the command of Lieutenant Colonel Thomas Gage PERSON , Washington GPE , still very ill, rallied the survivors and formed a rear guard, allowing the remnants of the force to disengage and retreat.[33]
During the engagement, he had two CARDINAL horses shot from under him, and his hat and coat were bullet-pierced.[34] His conduct under fire redeemed his reputation among critics of his command in the Battle of Fort Necessity,[35 LOC ] but he was not included by the succeeding commander (Colonel Thomas Dunbar PERSON ) in planning subsequent operations.[36]
The Virginia Regiment ORG was reconstituted in August 1755 DATE , and Dinwiddie ORG appointed Washington GPE its commander, again with the rank of colonel. Washington GPE clashed over seniority almost immediately, this time with John Dagworthy PERSON , another captain of superior royal rank, who commanded a detachment of Marylanders PRODUCT at the regiment's headquarters in Fort Cumberland.[37 GPE ] Washington GPE , impatient for an offensive against Fort Duquesne FAC , was convinced Braddock ORG would have granted him a royal commission and pressed his case in February 1756 DATE with Braddock ORG 's successor as Commander-in-Chief, William Shirley PERSON , and again in January 1757 DATE with Shirley PERSON 's successor, Lord Loudoun GPE . Shirley PERSON ruled in Washington GPE 's favor only in the matter of Dagworthy GPE ; Loudoun GPE humiliated Washington GPE , refused him a royal commission and agreed only to relieve him of the responsibility of manning Fort Cumberland.[38 FAC ]
In 1758 DATE , the Virginia Regiment ORG was assigned to the British NORP Forbes Expedition ORG to capture Fort Duquesne.[d][40 GPE ] Washington GPE disagreed with General John Forbes PERSON ' tactics and chosen route.[41] Forbes nevertheless made Washington GPE a brevet brigadier general and gave him command of one CARDINAL of the three CARDINAL brigades that would assault the fort. The French NORP had abandoned the fort and the valley before the assault, however, and Washington GPE only saw a friendly fire incident which left 14 CARDINAL dead and 26 CARDINAL injured. Frustrated, he resigned his commission soon afterwards and returned to Mount Vernon.[42 LOC ]
Under Washington GPE , the Virginia Regiment ORG had defended 300 miles QUANTITY ( 480 km QUANTITY ) of frontier against twenty CARDINAL Indian NORP attacks in ten CARDINAL months.[43] He increased the professionalism of the regiment as it grew from 300 CARDINAL to 1,000 CARDINAL men, and Virginia GPE 's frontier population suffered less than other colonies. Though he failed to realize a royal commission, he gained self-confidence, leadership skills, and knowledge of British NORP military tactics. The destructive competition Washington GPE witnessed among colonial politicians fostered his later support of a strong central government.[44]
On January 6, 1759 DATE , Washington GPE , at age 26 DATE , married Martha Dandridge Custis PERSON , the 27-year-old DATE widow of wealthy plantation owner Daniel Parke Custis ORG . The marriage took place at Martha PERSON 's estate; she was intelligent, gracious, and experienced in managing a planter's estate, and the couple had a happy marriage.[45] They moved to Mount Vernon GPE , near Alexandria GPE , where he lived as a planter of tobacco and wheat and emerged as a political figure.[46]
Washington GPE 's 1751 DATE bout with smallpox is thought to have rendered him sterile, though it is equally likely that " Martha PERSON may have sustained injury during the birth of Patsy PERSON , her final child, making additional births impossible."[47] The couple lamented not having any children together.[e][50] Despite this, the two CARDINAL raised Martha PERSON 's two CARDINAL children John Parke Custis ORG ( Jacky PERSON ) and Martha Parke Custis ORG ( Patsy PERSON ), and later Jacky PERSON 's two CARDINAL youngest children Eleanor Parke Custis ORG (Nelly) and George Washington Parke Custis ORG ( Washy PERSON ), along with numerous nieces and nephews.[51]
The marriage gave Washington GPE control over Martha PERSON 's one-third CARDINAL dower interest in the 18,000-acre QUANTITY ( 7,300 CARDINAL ha) Custis estate, and he managed the remaining two-thirds CARDINAL for Martha PERSON 's children; the estate also included 84 CARDINAL slaves. As a result, he became one of the wealthiest men in Virginia GPE , which increased his social standing.[52]
At Washington GPE 's urging, Governor Lord Botetourt fulfilled Dinwiddie ORG 's 1754 DATE promise of land bounties to all-volunteer militia during the French NORP and Indian NORP War.[53] In late 1770 DATE , Washington GPE inspected the lands in the Ohio GPE and Great Kanawha ORG regions, and he engaged surveyor William Crawford PERSON to subdivide it. Crawford ORG allotted 23,200 acres QUANTITY ( 9,400 CARDINAL ha) to Washington GPE ; Washington GPE told the veterans that their land was hilly and unsuitable for farming, and he agreed to purchase 20,147 acres QUANTITY ( 8,153 CARDINAL ha), leaving some feeling they had been duped.[54] He also doubled the size of Mount Vernon GPE to 6,500 acres QUANTITY ( 2,600 CARDINAL ha) and, by 1775 DATE , had increased its slave population by more than a hundred.[55]
As a respected military hero and large landowner, Washington GPE held local offices and was elected to the Virginia GPE provincial legislature, representing Frederick County GPE in the House of Burgesses ORG for seven years DATE beginning in 1758.[55] He first ORDINAL ran for the seat in 1755 DATE but was soundly beaten by Hugh PERSON West.[56][57] When he ran in 1758 DATE , Washington GPE plied voters with beer, brandy, and other beverages. Despite being away serving on the Forbes Expedition ORG , he won the election with roughly 40 percent PERCENT of the vote, defeating three CARDINAL opponents with the help of local supporters.[58][59]
Early in his legislative career, Washington GPE rarely spoke or even attended legislative sessions. He would later become a prominent critic of Britain GPE 's taxation policy and mercantilist policies towards the American NORP colonies and became more politically active starting in the 1760s.[60]
Washington GPE imported luxuries and other goods from England GPE , paying for them by exporting tobacco. His profligate spending combined with low tobacco prices left him 1,800 MONEY in debt by 1764 DATE , prompting him to diversify his holdings.[61] In 1765 DATE , because of erosion and other soil problems, he changed Mount Vernon's PERSON primary cash crop from tobacco to wheat and expanded operations to include corn flour milling and fishing.[62][63]
Washington GPE soon was counted among the political and social elite in Virginia GPE . From 1768 to 1775 DATE , he invited some 2,000 CARDINAL guests to Mount Vernon GPE , mostly those whom he considered people of rank, and was known to be exceptionally cordial toward guests.[64] Washington GPE also took time for leisure with fox hunting, fishing, dances, theater, cards, backgammon, and billiards.[65]
Washington GPE 's stepdaughter Patsy PERSON suffered from epileptic attacks from age 12 DATE , and she died in his arms in 1773 DATE . The following day, he wrote to Burwell Bassett PERSON : "It is easier to conceive, than to describe, the distress of this Family".[66] He canceled all business activity and remained with Martha PERSON every night for three CARDINAL months.[67]
Washington GPE played a central role before and during the American Revolution EVENT . His distrust of the British NORP military had begun when he was passed over for promotion into the Regular Army ORG . Opposed to taxes imposed by the British Parliament ORG on the Colonies GPE without proper representation,[68] he and other colonists were also angered by the Royal Proclamation of 1763 ORG which banned American NORP settlement west of the Allegheny Mountains LOC and protected the British NORP fur trade.[69]
Washington GPE believed the Stamp Act 1765 LAW was an "Act of Oppression" and celebrated its repeal the following year.[f] In March 1766 DATE , Parliament ORG passed the Declaratory Act LAW asserting that Parliamentary law superseded colonial law.[71] In the late 1760s DATE , the interference of the British Crown ORG in American NORP lucrative western land speculation spurred the American NORP Revolution.[72] Washington GPE was a prosperous land speculator, and in 1767 DATE , he encouraged "adventures" to acquire backcountry western lands.[72 ORG ] Washington GPE helped lead widespread protests against the Townshend ORG Acts passed by Parliament ORG in 1767 DATE , and he introduced a proposal in May 1769 DATE which urged Virginians NORP to boycott British NORP goods; the Acts were mostly repealed in 1770.[73 CARDINAL ]
Parliament ORG sought to punish Massachusetts GPE colonists for their role in the Boston Tea Party ORG in 1774 DATE by passing the Coercive Acts FAC , which Washington GPE saw as "an invasion of our rights and privileges".[74] He said Americans NORP must not submit to acts of tyranny since "custom and use shall make us as tame and abject slaves, as the blacks we rule over with such arbitrary sway".[75] That July DATE , he and George Mason PERSON drafted a list of resolutions for the Fairfax County GPE committee, including a call to end the Atlantic LOC slave trade, which were adopted.[76]
On August 1 DATE , Washington GPE attended the First Virginia Convention ORG . There, he was selected as a delegate to the First ORDINAL Continental Congress.[77] As tensions rose in 1774 DATE , he helped train militias in Virginia GPE and organized enforcement of the Continental Association ORG boycott of British NORP goods instituted by the Congress.[78]
The American Revolutionary War WORK_OF_ART broke out on April 19, 1775 DATE , with the Battles of Lexington GPE and Concord GPE and the Siege of Boston.[79 GPE ] Upon hearing the news, Washington GPE was "sobered and dismayed",[80] and he hastily departed Mount Vernon LOC on May 4, 1775 DATE , to join the Second Continental Congress ORG in Philadelphia.[81]
On June 14, 1775 DATE , Congress ORG created the Continental Army ORG and John Adams PERSON nominated Washington GPE as its commander-in-chief, mainly because of his military experience and the belief that a Virginian GPE would better unite the colonies. He was unanimously elected by Congress ORG the next day.[82 DATE ] Washington GPE appeared before Congress ORG in uniform and gave an acceptance speech on June 16 DATE , declining a salary, though he was later reimbursed expenses.[83]
Washington GPE was commissioned on June 19 DATE and officially appointed by Congress ORG as " General & Commander ORG in chief of the army of the United Colonies ORG and of all the forces raised or to be raised by them".[84] He was instructed to take charge of the Siege of Boston ORG on June 22 DATE , 1775.[85]
Congress ORG chose his primary staff officers, including Major General Artemas Ward PERSON , Adjutant General Horatio Gates PERSON , Major General Charles Lee PERSON , Major General Philip Schuyler PERSON , and Major General Nathanael Greene PERSON . [ 86 CARDINAL ] Henry Knox PERSON , a young bookkeeper, impressed Adams ORG and Washington GPE with ordnance knowledge and was subsequently promoted to colonel and chief of artillery. Similarly, Washington GPE was impressed by Alexander Hamilton's PERSON intelligence and bravery. He would later promote him to colonel and appoint him his aide-de-camp.[87]
Washington GPE initially banned the enlistment of blacks, both free and enslaved, into the Continental Army ORG . The British NORP saw an opportunity to divide the colonies, and the colonial governor of Virginia GPE issued a proclamation, which promised freedom to slaves if they joined the British.[88] Desperate for manpower by late 1777 DATE , Washington GPE relented and overturned his ban.[89] By the end of the war DATE , around one-tenth CARDINAL of Washington GPE 's army were blacks.[90] Following the British NORP surrender, Washington GPE sought to enforce terms of the preliminary Treaty of Paris GPE ( 1783 DATE ) by reclaiming slaves freed by the British NORP and returning them to servitude. He arranged to make this request to Sir Guy Carleton PERSON on May 6, 1783 DATE . Instead, Carleton PERSON issued 3,000 CARDINAL freedom certificates and all former slaves in New York City GPE were able to leave before the city was evacuated by the British NORP in late November 1783.[91]
Early in 1775 DATE , in response to the growing rebellious movement, London GPE sent British NORP troops to occupy Boston GPE , led by General Thomas Gage PERSON , commander of British NORP forces in America.[92] They set up fortifications, making the city impervious to attack. Local militias surrounded the city and effectively trapped the British NORP troops, resulting in a standoff.[93]
As Washington ORG headed for Boston GPE , word of his march preceded him, and he was greeted everywhere; gradually, he became a symbol of the Patriot cause.[94] Upon ORG arrival on July 2, 1775 DATE , two weeks DATE after the Battle of Bunker Hill LOC , he set up headquarters in Cambridge GPE . When he went to inspect the army, he found undisciplined militia.[95] After consultation, he initiated Benjamin Franklin's PERSON suggested reforms: drilling the soldiers and imposing strict discipline.[96] Washington GPE ordered his officers to identify the skills of recruits to ensure military effectiveness, while removing incompetent officers.[97] He petitioned Gage, his former superior, to release captured Patriot ORG officers from prison and treat them humanely.[98] In October 1775 DATE , King George III PERSON declared that the colonies were in open rebellion and relieved Gage of command for incompetence, replacing him with General William Howe.[99 PERSON ]
The Continental Army ORG , reduced to only 9,600 CARDINAL men by January 1776 DATE due to expiring short-term enlistments, had to be supplemented with militia. Soon, they were joined by Knox ORG with heavy artillery captured from Fort GPE Ticonderoga.[100] When the Charles River LOC froze over, Washington GPE was eager to cross and storm Boston GPE , but General Gates PERSON and others were opposed to untrained militia striking well-garrisoned fortifications. Instead, he agreed to secure the Dorchester Heights LOC , 100 feet QUANTITY above Boston GPE , with Knox ORG 's artillery to try to force the British NORP out.[101]
On March 9 DATE , under cover of darkness, Washington GPE 's troops bombarded British NORP ships in Boston GPE harbor. On March 17 DATE , 9,000 CARDINAL British NORP troops and Loyalists ORG began a chaotic ten-day DATE evacuation aboard 120 CARDINAL ships. Soon after, Washington GPE entered the city with 500 CARDINAL men, with explicit orders not to plunder the city.[102] He refrained from exerting military authority in Boston GPE , leaving civilian matters in the hands of local authorities.[g][104]
After the victory at Boston GPE , Washington GPE correctly guessed that the British NORP would return to New York City GPE , a Loyalist ORG stronghold, and retaliate. He arrived there on April 13, 1776 DATE , and ordered the construction of fortifications to thwart the expected British NORP attack. He also ordered his occupying forces to treat civilians and their property with respect, to avoid the abuses Bostonians NORP suffered at the hands of British NORP troops.[105]
Howe transported his resupplied army, with the British NORP fleet, from Halifax ORG to New York City GPE . George Germain PERSON , who ran the British NORP war effort in England GPE , believed it could be won with one "decisive blow".[106] The British NORP forces, including more than a hundred CARDINAL ships and thousands CARDINAL of troops, began arriving on Staten Island LOC on July 2 DATE to lay siege to the city.[107] After the Declaration of Independence WORK_OF_ART was unanimously adopted on July 4 DATE , Washington GPE informed his troops on July 9 DATE that Congress ORG had declared the united colonies to be "free and independent states".[108]
Howe ORG 's troop strength totaled 32,000 CARDINAL regulars and Hessian NORP auxiliaries, and Washington GPE 's consisted of 23,000 CARDINAL , mostly raw recruits and militia.[109] In August DATE , Howe ORG landed 20,000 CARDINAL troops at Gravesend GPE , Brooklyn GPE , and approached Washington GPE 's fortifications Opposing his generals, Washington GPE chose to fight, based on inaccurate information that Howe ORG 's army had only 8,000-plus CARDINAL troops.[110] In the Battle of Long Island LOC , Howe assaulted Washington GPE 's flank and inflicted 1,500 CARDINAL Patriot casualties, the British NORP suffering 400.[111 CARDINAL ] Washington GPE retreated, instructing General William Heath PERSON to acquire river craft. On August 30 DATE , General William Stirling PERSON held off the British NORP and gave cover while the army crossed the East River LOC under darkness to Manhattan GPE without loss of life or materiel, although Alexander ORG was captured.[112]
Howe PERSON was emboldened by his Long Island LOC victory and dispatched Washington GPE as " George Washington PERSON , Esq GPE ." in futility to negotiate peace. Washington ORG declined, demanding to be addressed with diplomatic protocol, as general and fellow belligerent, not as a "rebel", lest his men be hanged as such if captured.[113] The Royal Navy ORG bombarded the unstable earthworks on lower Manhattan GPE Island.[114] Despite misgivings, Washington GPE heeded the advice of Generals Greene FAC and Putnam ORG to defend Fort Washington FAC . They were unable to hold it; Washington GPE abandoned the fort and ordered his army north to the White Plains.[115] FAC Howe PERSON 's pursuit forced Washington GPE to retreat across the Hudson River LOC to Fort Lee GPE to avoid encirclement. Howe landed his troops on Manhattan GPE in November DATE and captured Fort Washington FAC , inflicting high casualties on the Americans NORP . Washington GPE was responsible for delaying the retreat, though he blamed Congress ORG and General Greene PERSON . Loyalists in New York City GPE considered Howe a liberator and spread a rumor that Washington GPE had set fire to the city.[116] Patriot morale reached its lowest when Lee PERSON was captured.[117] Now reduced to 5,400 CARDINAL troops, Washington GPE 's army retreated through New Jersey GPE , and Howe PERSON broke off pursuit to set up winter quarters DATE in New York.[118 GPE ]
Washington GPE crossed the Delaware River LOC into Pennsylvania GPE , where Lee PERSON 's replacement General John Sullivan PERSON joined him with 2,000 CARDINAL more troops.[119] The future of the Continental Army ORG was in doubt due to lack of supplies, a harsh winter DATE , expiring enlistments, and desertions. Washington GPE was disappointed that many New Jersey GPE residents were Loyalists ORG or skeptical about independence.[120]
Howe split up his army and posted a Hessian NORP garrison at Trenton GPE to hold western New Jersey GPE and the east shore of the Delaware.[121] Desperate for a victory, Washington GPE and his generals devised a surprise attack on Trenton GPE . The army was to cross the Delaware FAC in three CARDINAL divisions: one led by Washington GPE ( 2,400 CARDINAL troops), another by General James Ewing PERSON ( 700 CARDINAL ), and the third ORDINAL by Colonel John Cadwalader PERSON ( 1,500 CARDINAL ). The force was to then split, with Washington GPE taking the Pennington Road ORG and General Sullivan PERSON traveling south on the river's edge.[122]
Washington GPE ordered a 60-mile QUANTITY search for Durham GPE boats to transport his army, and the destruction of vessels that could be used by the British.[123] He personally risked capture while staking out the Jersey GPE shoreline alone leading up to the crossing. Washington GPE crossed the Delaware GPE on Christmas night TIME , 1776.[124 CARDINAL ] His men followed across the ice-obstructed river from McConkey ORG 's Ferry PRODUCT , with 40 CARDINAL men per vessel. The wind churned up the waters, and they were pelted with hail, but by 3:00 a.m. TIME on December 26 DATE , they made it across with no losses.[125] Knox PERSON was delayed, managing frightened horses and about 18 CARDINAL field guns on flat-bottomed ferries. Cadwalader and Ewing failed to cross due to the ice and heavy currents. Once Knox PERSON arrived, Washington GPE proceeded to Trenton GPE , rather than risk being spotted returning his army to Pennsylvania.[126]
The troops spotted Hessian NORP positions a mile QUANTITY from Trenton GPE , so Washington GPE split his force into two CARDINAL columns, rallying his men: "Soldiers keep by your officers. For God's sake, keep by your officers." The two CARDINAL columns were separated at the Birmingham GPE crossroads. General Greene PERSON 's column took the upper Ferry Road WORK_OF_ART , led by Washington GPE , and General Sullivan PERSON 's column advanced on River Road.[127 FAC ] The Americans NORP marched in sleet and snowfall. Many were shoeless with bloodied feet, and two CARDINAL died of exposure. At sunrise, Washington GPE , aided by Colonel Knox PERSON and artillery, led his men in a surprise attack on the unsuspecting Hessians NORP and their commander, Colonel Johann Rall PERSON . The Hessians NORP had 22 CARDINAL killed, including Colonel Rall PERSON , 83 CARDINAL wounded, and 850 CARDINAL captured with supplies.[128]
Washington GPE retreated across the Delaware GPE to Pennsylvania GPE and returned to New Jersey GPE on January 3, 1777 DATE , launching an attack on British NORP regulars at Princeton GPE , with 40 CARDINAL Americans NORP killed or wounded and 273 CARDINAL British NORP killed or captured.[129] American Generals Hugh Mercer and John Cadwalader PERSON were being driven back by the British NORP when Mercer PERSON was mortally wounded. Washington GPE arrived and led the men in a counterattack which advanced to within 30 yards QUANTITY ( 27 CARDINAL m) of the British NORP line.[130]
Some British NORP troops retreated after a brief stand, while others took refuge in Nassau Hall GPE , which became the target of Colonel Alexander Hamilton PERSON 's cannons. Washington GPE 's troops charged, the British NORP surrendered in less than an hour TIME , and 194 CARDINAL soldiers laid down their arms.[131] Howe retreated to New York City GPE where his army remained inactive until early the next year.[132 PERSON ] Washington GPE took up winter DATE headquarters in Jacob Arnold's PERSON Tavern in Morristown GPE , New Jersey,[133] while he received munition from the Hibernia mines.[134] While in Morristown GPE , Washington GPE 's troops disrupted British NORP supply lines and expelled them from parts of New Jersey.[135]
During his stay in Morristown GPE , Washington GPE ordered the inoculation of Continental ORG troops against smallpox. This went against the wishes of the Continental Congress ORG who had issued a proclamation prohibiting it, but Washington GPE feared the spread of smallpox in the army. The mass inoculation proved successful, with only isolated infections occurring and no regiments incapacitated by the disease.[136]
The British NORP still controlled New York GPE , and many Patriot ORG soldiers did not re-enlist or deserted after the harsh winter DATE campaign. Congress ORG instituted greater rewards for re-enlisting and punishments for desertion to effect greater troop numbers.[137] Strategically, Washington GPE 's victories at Trenton GPE and Princeton PERSON were pivotal; they revived Patriot PERSON morale and quashed the British NORP strategy of showing overwhelming force followed by offering generous terms, changing the course of the war.[138][124] In February 1777 DATE , word of the American NORP victories reached London GPE , and the British NORP realized the Patriots ORG were in a position to demand unconditional independence.[139]
In July 1777 DATE , British NORP General John Burgoyne PERSON led the Saratoga NORP campaign south from Quebec GPE through Lake Champlain LOC and recaptured Fort Ticonderoga ORG intending to divide New England LOC , including control of the Hudson River LOC . However, General Howe PERSON in British NORP -occupied New York City GPE blundered, taking his army south to Philadelphia GPE rather than up the Hudson River LOC to join Burgoyne PERSON near Albany.[140]
Washington GPE and Gilbert du Motier PERSON , Marquis de Lafayette PERSON rushed to Philadelphia GPE to engage Howe. In the Battle of Brandywine LOC , on September 11, 1777 DATE , Howe PERSON outmaneuvered Washington GPE and marched unopposed into the nation's capital at Philadelphia GPE . A Patriot ORG attack failed against the British NORP at Germantown GPE in October.[141]
In Upstate New York GPE , the Patriots ORG were led by General Horatio Gates PERSON . Concerned about Burgoyne ORG 's movements southward, Washington GPE sent reinforcements north with Generals Benedict Arnold PERSON , his most aggressive field commander, and Benjamin Lincoln PERSON . On October 7, 1777 DATE , Burgoyne PERSON tried to take Bemis Heights GPE but was isolated from support by Howe PERSON . He was forced to retreat to Saratoga NORP and ultimately surrendered after the Battles of Saratoga NORP . As Washington GPE suspected, Gates ORG ' victory emboldened his critics.[142]
Biographer John Alden PERSON maintains, "It was inevitable that the defeats of Washington GPE 's forces and the concurrent victory of the forces in upper New York GPE should be compared." Admiration for Washington GPE was waning, including little credit from John Adams.[143][144] PERSON Washington GPE and his Continental Army ORG of 11,000 CARDINAL men went into winter quarters DATE at Valley Forge LOC north of Philadelphia GPE in December 1777 DATE . There they lost between 2,000 and 3,000 CARDINAL men as a result of disease and lack of food, clothing, and shelter.[145] The British NORP were comfortably quartered in Philadelphia GPE , paying for supplies in pounds sterling, while Washington GPE struggled with a devalued American NORP paper currency. The woodlands were soon exhausted of game. By February DATE , Washington GPE was facing lowered morale and increased desertions among his troops.[146]
An internal revolt by his officers, led by Major General Thomas Conway PERSON , prompted some members of Congress ORG to consider removing Washington GPE from command. Washington GPE 's supporters resisted, and the matter was dropped after much deliberation.[147] PERSON Once the plot was exposed, Conway ORG wrote an apology to Washington GPE , resigned, and returned to France.[148]
Washington GPE made repeated petitions to Congress ORG for provisions. He received a congressional delegation to check the Army ORG 's conditions and expressed the urgency of the situation, proclaiming: "Something must be done. Important alterations must be made." He recommended that Congress ORG expedite supplies, and Congress ORG agreed to strengthen and fund the army's supply lines by reorganizing the commissary department. By late February DATE , supplies began arriving.[103] Meanwhile, Baron Friedrich Wilhelm PERSON von Steuben's PERSON incessant drilling transformed Washington GPE 's recruits into a disciplined fighting force by the end of winter DATE camp.[149] For his services, Washington GPE promoted Von Steuben PERSON to Major General ORG and made him chief of staff.[150][151]
In early 1778 DATE , the French NORP responded to Burgoyne ORG 's defeat and entered into a Treaty of Alliance with the Americans NORP . Congress ORG ratified the treaty in May DATE , which amounted to a French NORP declaration of war against Britain.[152] In May 1778 DATE , Howe PERSON resigned and was replaced by Sir Henry PERSON Clinton.[153]
The British NORP evacuated Philadelphia GPE for New York GPE that June and Washington GPE summoned a war council of American NORP and French NORP generals. He chose a partial attack on the retreating British NORP at the Battle of Monmouth LOC . Generals Charles Lee PERSON and Lafayette PERSON moved with 4,000 CARDINAL men, without Washington GPE 's knowledge, and bungled their first ORDINAL attack on June 28 DATE . Washington GPE relieved Lee PERSON and achieved a draw after an expansive battle. At nightfall, the British NORP continued their retreat to New York GPE , and Washington GPE moved his army outside the city.[154] Monmouth GPE was Washington GPE 's last battle in the North.[155]
Washington GPE became America GPE 's first ORDINAL spymaster by designing an espionage system against the British.[156] In 1778 DATE , Major Benjamin Tallmadge PERSON formed the Culper Ring ORG at Washington GPE 's direction to covertly collect information about the British NORP in New York.[157] Washington GPE had disregarded incidents of disloyalty by Benedict Arnold PERSON , who had distinguished himself in many battles.[158]
In 1780 DATE , Arnold PERSON began supplying British NORP spymaster John PERSON Andre with sensitive information intended to compromise Washington GPE and capture West Point LOC , a key American NORP defensive position on the Hudson PERSON River.[159] Historians Nathaniel Philbrick PERSON and Ron Chernow PERSON noted possible reasons for Arnold PERSON 's defection to be his anger at losing promotions to junior officers, or repeated slights from Congress ORG . He was also deeply in debt, profiteering from the war, and disappointed by Washington GPE 's lack of support during his eventual court-martial.[160]
After repeated requests, Washington GPE agreed to give Arnold PERSON command of West Point LOC in August.[161] On September 21 DATE , Arnold PERSON met Andre and gave him plans to take over the garrison.[162] While returning to British NORP lines, Andre was captured by militia who discovered the plans; upon hearing the news of Andre PRODUCT 's capture on September 24 DATE , while waiting to greet and have breakfast with Washington GPE , Arnold PERSON immediately fleed to the HMS Vulture WORK_OF_ART , the ship that had brought Andre to West Point GPE , and escaped to New York.[163]
Upon being told about Arnold PERSON 's treason, Washington GPE recalled the commanders positioned under Arnold PERSON at key points around the fort to prevent any complicity. He assumed personal command at West Point LOC and reorganized its defenses.[164] Andre's trial for espionage ended in a death sentence, and Washington GPE offered to return him to the British NORP in exchange for Arnold PERSON , but Clinton PERSON refused. Andre was hanged on October 2, 1780 DATE , despite his request for a firing squad, to deter other spies.[165]
In late 1778 DATE , General Clinton PERSON shipped 3,000 CARDINAL troops from New York GPE to Georgia GPE and launched a Southern NORP invasion against Savannah GPE , reinforced by 2,000 CARDINAL British NORP and Loyalist ORG troops. They repelled an attack by American NORP patriots and French NORP naval forces, which bolstered the British NORP war effort.[166]
In June 1778 DATE , Iroquois NORP warriors joined with Loyalist ORG rangers led by Walter Butler PERSON and killed more than 200 CARDINAL frontiersmen, laying waste to the Wyoming Valley LOC in Northeastern Pennsylvania.[167] In mid-1779 DATE , in response to this and other attacks on New England LOC towns, Washington GPE ordered General John Sullivan PERSON to lead an expedition to force the Iroquois NORP out of New York GPE by effecting "the total destruction and devastation" of their villages and taking their women and children hostage.[168][169] The expedition systematically destroyed Iroquois NORP villages and food stocks, and forced at least 5,036 CARDINAL Iroquois NORP to flee to British Canada ORG . The campaign directly killed a few hundred CARDINAL Iroquois GPE , but according to historian Rhiannon Koehler PERSON , the net effect was to reduce the Iroquois NORP by half CARDINAL . They became unable to survive the harsh winter of 17791780 DATE ; some historians now described the campaign as a genocide.[170]
Washington GPE 's troops went into quarters at Morristown GPE , New Jersey GPE for their worst winter DATE of the war, with temperatures well below freezing. New York Harbor LOC was frozen, snow covered the ground for weeks DATE , and the troops again lacked provisions.[171]
In January 1780 DATE , Clinton PERSON assembled 12,500 CARDINAL troops and attacked Charles Town PERSON , South Carolina GPE , defeating General Benjamin Lincoln PERSON . By June DATE , they occupied the South Carolina GPE Piedmont.[172] Clinton PERSON returned to New York GPE and left 8,000 CARDINAL troops under the command of General Charles Cornwallis.[173] PERSON Congress ORG replaced Lincoln ORG with Horatio Gates ORG ; after his defeat in the Battle of Camden LOC , Gates ORG was replaced by Nathanael Greene PERSON , Washington GPE 's initial choice, but the British NORP had firm control of the South LOC . Washington GPE was reinvigorated, however, when Lafayette PERSON returned from France GPE with more ships, men, and supplies,[174] and 5,000 CARDINAL veteran French NORP troops led by Marshal Rochambeau ORG arrived at Newport GPE , Rhode Island GPE in July 1780.[175 DATE ] French NORP naval forces then landed, led by Admiral de Grasse.[176] ORG Washington GPE 's army went into winter quarters DATE at New Windsor GPE , New York GPE in December 1780 DATE ; he urged Congress ORG and state officials to expedite provisions so the army would not "continue to struggle under the same difficulties they have hitherto endured".[177] On March 1, 1781 DATE , Congress ORG ratified the Articles of Confederation ORG , but the government that took effect on March 2 DATE did not have the power to levy taxes, and it loosely held the states together.[178 PERSON ]
General Clinton PERSON sent Benedict Arnold PERSON , now a British NORP Brigadier General with 1,700 CARDINAL troops, to Virginia GPE to capture Portsmouth ORG and conduct raids on Patriot ORG forces; Washington GPE responded by sending Lafayette ORG south to counter Arnold PERSON 's efforts.[179] Washington GPE initially hoped to bring the fight to New York GPE , drawing off British NORP forces from Virginia GPE and ending the war there, but Rochambeau ORG advised him that Cornwallis PERSON in Virginia GPE was the better target. De Grasse's ORG fleet arrived off the Virginia GPE coast, cutting off British NORP retreat. Seeing the advantage, Washington GPE made a feint towards Clinton PERSON in New York GPE , then headed south to Virginia.[180]
The siege of Yorktown GPE was a decisive victory by the combined forces of the Continental Army ORG commanded by Washington GPE , the French Army ORG commanded by General Comte de Rochambeau PERSON , and the French NORP Navy ORG commanded by Admiral de Grasse ORG . On August 19 DATE , the march to Yorktown PERSON led by Washington GPE and Rochambeau ORG began, which is known now as the "celebrated march".[181] Washington GPE was in command of an army of 7,800 CARDINAL Frenchmen, 3,100 CARDINAL militia, and 8,000 CARDINAL Continentals. Inexperienced in siege warfare, he often deferred to the judgment of General Rochambeau PERSON and relied on his advice. Despite this, Rochambeau ORG never challenged Washington GPE 's authority as the battle's commanding officer.[182 PRODUCT ]
By late September DATE , Patriot-French ORG forces surrounded Yorktown GPE , trapped the British Army ORG , and prevented British NORP reinforcements from Clinton PERSON in the North LOC , while the French NORP navy emerged victorious at the Battle of the Chesapeake LOC . The final American NORP offensive began with a shot fired by Washington.[183] The siege ended with a British NORP surrender on October 19, 1781 DATE ; over 7,000 CARDINAL British NORP soldiers became prisoners of war.[184 PERSON ] Washington GPE negotiated the terms of surrender for two days DATE , and the official signing ceremony took place on October 19 DATE ; Cornwallis PERSON claimed illness and was absent, sending General Charles O'Hara PERSON as his proxy. [ 185 CARDINAL ] As a gesture of goodwill, Washington GPE held a dinner for the American NORP , French NORP , and British NORP generals, all of whom fraternized on friendly terms and identified with one another as members of the same professional military caste.[186 PERSON ]
Afterwards NORP , Washington GPE moved the army to New Windsor GPE , New York GPE where they remained stationed until the Treaty of Paris ORG was signed on September 3, 1783 DATE , formally ending the war. Although the peace treaty did not happen for two years DATE following the end of the battle, Yorktown PERSON proved to be the last significant battle or campaign of the Revolutionary War EVENT , with the British NORP Parliament agreeing to cease hostilities in March 1782.[187 DATE ]
When peace negotiations began in April 1782 DATE , both the British NORP and French NORP began gradually evacuating their forces.[188 PRODUCT ] With the American NORP treasury empty, unpaid and mutinous soldiers forced the adjournment of Congress ORG . In March 1783 DATE , Washington GPE successfully calmed the Newburgh Conspiracy LAW , a planned munity by American NORP officers; Congress ORG promised each a five-year DATE bonus.[189] PERSON Washington GPE submitted an account of $ 450,000 MONEY in expenses which he had advanced to the army, equivalent to $9.15 million MONEY in 2022 DATE . The account was settled, though it was allegedly vague about large sums and included expenses his wife had incurred through visits to his headquarters.[190]
The following month, a Congressional NORP committee led by Alexander Hamilton PERSON began adapting the army for peacetime. In August 1783 DATE , Washington GPE gave the Army ORG 's perspective to the committee in his Sentiments on a Peace Establishment WORK_OF_ART , which advised Congress ORG to keep a standing army, create a "national militia" of separate state units, and establish a navy and a national military academy.[191] PERSON The Treaty of Paris WORK_OF_ART was signed on September 3, 1783 DATE , and Britain GPE officially recognized American NORP independence. Washington GPE disbanded his army, giving a farewell address to his soldiers on November 2.[192 DATE ] During this time, Washington GPE oversaw the evacuation of British NORP forces in New York GPE and was greeted by parades and celebrations.[193] PERSON Along with Governor George Clinton PERSON , he took formal possession of the city on November 25.[194 DATE ]
In early December 1783 DATE , Washington GPE bade farewell to his officers at Fraunces Tavern ORG and resigned as commander-in-chief soon thereafter.[195] In a final appearance in uniform, he gave a statement to the Congress ORG : "I consider it an indispensable duty to close this last solemn act of my official life, by commending the interests of our dearest country to the protection of Almighty God, and those who have the superintendence of them, to his holy keeping."[196] Washington GPE 's resignation was acclaimed at home and abroad and showed a skeptical world that the new republic would not degenerate into chaos.[h][198]
The same month DATE , Washington GPE was appointed president-general of the Society of the Cincinnati ORG , a newly established hereditary fraternity of Revolutionary War EVENT officers. He served in this capacity for the remainder of his life.[i][200]
"I am not only retired from all public employments but I am retiring within myself, and shall be able to view the solitary walk and tread the paths of private life with heartfelt satisfaction ... I will move gently down the stream of life, until I sleep with my fathers."
George Washington PERSON in a letter to Lafayette ORG . February 1 DATE , 1784.[201 CARDINAL ]
Washington GPE was longing to return home after spending just ten days DATE at Mount Vernon LOC out of 8+12 years DATE of war. He arrived on Christmas Eve DATE , delighted to be "free of the bustle of a camp and the busy scenes of public life".[202] He was a celebrity and was feted during a visit to his mother at Fredericksburg GPE in February 1784 DATE , and he received a constant stream of visitors wishing to pay their respects at Mount Vernon.[203 LOC ]
Washington GPE reactivated his interests in the Great Dismal Swamp FAC and Potomac NORP canal projects begun before the war, though neither paid him any dividends, and he undertook a 34-day DATE , 680-mile QUANTITY ( 1,090 km QUANTITY ) trip to check on his land holdings in the Ohio GPE Country.[204] He oversaw the completion of the remodeling work at Mount Vernon GPE , which transformed his residence into the mansion that survives to this day DATE although his financial situation was not strong. Creditors paid him in depreciated wartime currency, and he owed significant amounts in taxes and wages. Mount Vernon GPE had made no profit during his absence, and he saw persistently poor crop yields due to pestilence and poor weather. His estate recorded its eleventh year DATE running at a deficit in 1787 DATE , and there was little prospect of improvement.[205]
To make his estate profitable again, Washington GPE undertook a new landscaping plan and succeeded in cultivating a range of fast-growing trees and native shrubs.[206] He also began breeding mules after being gifted a Spanish NORP jack by King Charles III PERSON of Spain GPE in 1784 DATE . There were few mules in the United States GPE at that time, and he believed that they would revolutionize agriculture and transportation.[207 CARDINAL ]
Before returning to private life in June 1783 DATE , Washington GPE called for a strong union. Though he was concerned that he might be criticized for meddling in civil matters, he sent a circular letter to the states, maintaining that the Articles of Confederation ORG was no more than "a rope of sand". He believed the nation was on the verge of "anarchy and confusion", was vulnerable to foreign intervention, and that a national constitution would unify the states under a strong central government.[208]
When Shays' Rebellion erupted in Massachusetts GPE over taxation, Washington GPE was further convinced that a national constitution was needed.[209] Some nationalists feared that the new republic had descended into lawlessness, and they met on September 11, 1786 DATE , at Annapolis ORG to ask Congress ORG to revise the Articles of Confederation ORG . One CARDINAL of their biggest efforts was getting Washington GPE to attend.[210] Congress ORG agreed to a Constitutional Convention LAW to be held in Philadelphia GPE in Spring 1787 DATE , with each state to send delegates.[211]
On December 4, 1786 DATE , Washington GPE was chosen to lead the Virginia GPE delegation, but he declined on December 21 DATE . He had concerns about the legality of the convention and consulted James Madison PERSON , Henry Knox PERSON , and others. They persuaded him to attend as his presence might induce reluctant states to send delegates and smooth the way for the ratification process while also giving legitimacy to the convention.[212] On March 28 DATE , Washington GPE told Governor Edmund Randolph PERSON that he would attend the convention but made it clear that he was urged to attend.[213]
Washington GPE arrived in Philadelphia GPE on May 9, 1787 DATE , though a quorum was not attained until May 25 DATE . Benjamin Franklin PERSON nominated Washington GPE to preside over the convention, and he was unanimously elected to serve as president general.[214] The convention's state-mandated purpose was to revise the Articles of Confederation ORG , and the new government would be established when the resulting document was "duly confirmed by the several states".[215] Randolph introduced Madison PERSON 's Virginia Plan PERSON on May 27 DATE , the third day DATE of the convention. It called for an entirely new constitution and a sovereign national government, which Washington GPE highly recommended.[216]
On July 10 DATE , Washington GPE wrote to Alexander Hamilton PERSON : "I almost despair of seeing a favorable issue to the proceedings of our convention and do therefore repent having had any agency in the business."[217] Nevertheless, he lent his prestige to the work of the other delegates, unsuccessfully lobbying many to support ratification of the Constitution LAW , such as anti-federalists Edmund Randolph PERSON and George Mason.[218 PERSON ] The final version was voted on and signed by 39 CARDINAL of 55 CARDINAL delegates on September 17, 1787 DATE .
In 1788 DATE , the Board of Visitors ORG of the College of William & Mary ORG decided to re-establish the position of Chancellor, and elected Washington GPE to the office on January 18.[219 DATE ] The College Rector Samuel Griffin PERSON wrote to Washington GPE inviting him to the post, and in a letter dated April 30, 1788 DATE , Washington GPE accepted the position of the 14th ORDINAL Chancellor of the College of William & Mary.[220 ORG ] He continued to serve through his presidency until his death on December 14 DATE , 1799.[219 CARDINAL ]
The delegates to the Convention ORG anticipated a Washington GPE presidency and left it to him to define the office once elected.[j][217]
