The state electors under the Constitution LAW voted for the president on February 4, 1789 DATE , and Washington GPE suspected that most republicans NORP had not voted for him.[222] The mandated March 4 DATE date passed without a Congressional NORP quorum to count the votes, but a quorum was reached on April 5 DATE . The votes were tallied the next day DATE , and Washington GPE won the majority of every state's electoral votes. He was informed of his election as president by Congressional NORP Secretary Charles PERSON Thomson.[223] John Adams PERSON received the next highest number of votes and was elected vice president.[224] Despite feeling "anxious and painful sensations" about leaving Mount Vernon LOC , he departed for New York City GPE on April 16 DATE to be inaugurated.[225][226]
Washington GPE was inaugurated on April 30, 1789 DATE , taking the oath of office at Federal Hall ORG in New York GPE City.[k][228] His coach was led by militia and a marching band and followed by statesmen and foreign dignitaries in an inaugural parade, with a crowd of 10,000.[229 CARDINAL ] Chancellor Robert R. Livingston PERSON administered the oath, using a Bible WORK_OF_ART provided by the Masons, after which the militia fired a 13 CARDINAL -gun salute.[230] Washington GPE read a speech in the Senate Chamber ORG , asking "that Almighty Being ... consecrate the liberties and happiness of the people of the United ORG States".[231] Though he wished to serve without a salary, Congress ORG insisted that he accept it, later providing Washington GPE $ 25,000 MONEY per year to defray costs of the presidency, equivalent to $6.14 million MONEY today.[232]
Washington GPE wrote to James Madison PERSON : "As the first ORDINAL of everything in our situation will serve to establish a precedent, it is devoutly wished on my part that these precedents be fixed on true principles."[233] To that end, he preferred the title "Mr. President" over more majestic names proposed by the Senate ORG , including "His Excellency" and " His Highness the President".[234] WORK_OF_ART His executive precedents included the inaugural address, messages to Congress ORG , and the cabinet form of the executive branch.[235]
Washington GPE planned to resign after his first ORDINAL term, but political strife convinced him to remain in office.[236] He was an able administrator and a judge of talent and character, and he regularly talked with department heads to get their advice.[237] He tolerated opposing views, despite fears that a democratic system would lead to political violence, and he conducted a smooth transition of power to his successor.[238] He remained non-partisan throughout his presidency and opposed the divisiveness of political parties, but he favored a strong central government, was sympathetic to a Federalist NORP form of government, and leery of the Republican NORP opposition.[239]
Washington GPE dealt with major problems. The old Confederation ORG lacked the powers to handle its workload and had weak leadership, no executive, a small bureaucracy of clerks, large debt, worthless paper money, and no power to establish taxes.[240] He had the task of assembling an executive department and relied on Tobias Lear PERSON for advice selecting its officers.[241] Britain GPE refused to relinquish its forts in the American NORP West,[240] and Barbary PERSON pirates preyed on American NORP merchant ships in the Mediterranean LOC before the United States GPE even had a navy.[242 NORP ]
Congress ORG created executive departments in 1789 DATE , including the State Department ORG in July DATE , the War Department ORG in August DATE , and the Treasury Department ORG in September DATE . Washington GPE appointed Edmund Randolph PERSON as Attorney General, Samuel Osgood PERSON as Postmaster General, Thomas Jefferson PERSON as Secretary of State ORG , Henry Knox PERSON as Secretary of War, and Alexander Hamilton PERSON as Secretary of the Treasury ORG . Washington GPE 's cabinet became a consulting and advisory body, not mandated by the Constitution.[243 CARDINAL ]
Washington GPE 's cabinet members formed rival parties with sharply opposing views, most fiercely illustrated between Hamilton PERSON and Jefferson.[244] PERSON Washington GPE restricted cabinet discussions to topics of his choosing, without participating in the debate. He occasionally requested cabinet opinions in writing and expected department heads to agreeably carry out his decisions.[240]
Washington GPE was apolitical and opposed the formation of parties, suspecting that conflict would undermine republicanism.[245] He exercised great restraint in using his veto power, writing that "I give my Signature to many Bills GPE with which my Judgment PRODUCT is at variance..."[246]
His closest advisors formed two CARDINAL factions, portending the First Party System ORG . Secretary of the Treasury ORG Alexander Hamilton PERSON formed the Federalist Party ORG to promote national credit and a financially powerful nation. Secretary of State ORG Thomas Jefferson PERSON opposed Hamilton PERSON 's agenda and founded the Jeffersonian NORP Republicans NORP . Washington GPE favored Hamilton PERSON 's agenda, however, and it ultimately went into effectresulting in bitter controversy.[247]
Washington GPE proclaimed November 26, 1789 DATE , as a day of DATE Thanksgiving DATE to encourage national unity. "It is the duty of all nations to acknowledge the providence of Almighty God, to obey His will, to be grateful for His benefits, and humbly to implore His protection and favor." He spent that day DATE fasting and visiting debtors in prison to provide them with food and beer.[248]
In response to two CARDINAL antislavery petitions that were presented to Congress ORG in 1790 DATE , slaveholders in Georgia GPE and South Carolina GPE threatened to "blow the trumpet of civil war". Washington ORG and Congress ORG responded with a series of racist measures: naturalization was denied to black immigrants; blacks were barred from serving in state militias; the Southwest Territory ORG (later the state of Tennessee GPE ) was permitted to maintain slavery; and two CARDINAL more slave states were admitted ( Kentucky GPE in 1792 DATE and Tennessee GPE in 1796 DATE ). On February 12, 1793 DATE , Washington GPE signed into law the Fugitive Slave Act LAW , which overrode state laws and courts, allowing agents to cross state lines to return escaped slaves.[249] Many free blacks in the north decried the law believing it would allow bounty hunting and kidnapping. The Fugitive Slave Act LAW gave effect to the Constitution's Fugitive Slave Clause LAW , and the Act was passed overwhelmingly in Congress.[250]
At the same time, Washington GPE signed a reenactment of the Northwest Ordinance GPE in 1789 DATE , which had freed all slaves brought after 1787 DATE into a vast expanse of federal territory north of the Ohio River LOC , except for slaves escaping from slave states.[251][252 CARDINAL ] The 1787 DATE law lapsed when the new U.S. Constitution was ratified in 1789.[253 CARDINAL ] He also signed the Slave Trade Act of 1794 LAW , which sharply limited American NORP involvement in the Atlantic LOC slave trade.[254] On February 18, 1791 DATE , Congress ORG admitted the free state of Vermont GPE into the Union as the 14th ORDINAL state as of March 4 DATE , 1791.[255]
Washington GPE 's first ORDINAL term was largely devoted to economic concerns.[256] Establishment of public credit became a primary challenge for the federal government.[257] Hamilton PERSON submitted a report to a deadlocked Congress ORG , and he, Madison PERSON , and Jefferson PERSON reached the Compromise of 1790 DATE in which Jefferson ORG agreed to Hamilton PERSON 's debt proposals in exchange for moving the nation's capital temporarily to Philadelphia GPE and then south near Georgetown GPE on the Potomac NORP River.[247] The terms were legislated in the Funding Act LAW of 1790 DATE and the Residence Act LAW , both of which Washington GPE signed into law. Congress ORG authorized the assumption and payment of the nation's debts, with funding provided by customs duties and excise taxes.[258]
Hamilton PERSON caused controversy in Cabinet ORG by advocating for the establishment of the First Bank of the United States ORG . Madison PERSON and Jefferson PERSON objected to the idea, but legislation creating the bank easily passed Congress ORG . Jefferson PERSON and Randolph ORG insisted the federal government was going beyond its constitutional authority. Hamilton PERSON argued the government could charter the bank under the implied powers granted by the constitution. Washington GPE sided with Hamilton PERSON and signed the bank legislation on February 25, 1791 DATE . The rift between Hamilton PERSON and Jefferson PERSON , meanwhile, became openly hostile.[259]
The nation's first ORDINAL financial crisis occurred in March 1792 DATE . Hamilton PERSON 's Federalists exploited large loans to gain control of U.S. GPE debt securities, causing a run on the national bank;[260] the markets returned to normal by mid-April.[261] Jefferson PERSON believed Hamilton PERSON was part of the scheme, despite Hamilton PERSON 's efforts to ameliorate.[262]
Jefferson PERSON and Hamilton PERSON adopted diametrically opposed political principles. Hamilton PERSON believed in a strong national government requiring a national bank and foreign loans to function, while Jefferson PERSON believed the states and the farm element should primarily direct the government; he also resented the idea of banks and foreign loans. To Washington GPE 's dismay, the two CARDINAL men persistently entered into disputes and infighting.[263] Hamilton PERSON demanded that Jefferson PERSON resign if he could not support Washington GPE , and Jefferson PERSON told Washington GPE that Hamilton PERSON 's fiscal system would lead to the overthrow of the republic.[264] Washington GPE urged them to call a truce for the sake of the nation, but they ignored him.[265]
Jefferson PERSON 's political actions, his support of Freneau's ORG National Gazette,[266] and his attempts to undermine Hamilton PERSON nearly led Washington GPE to dismiss him from the cabinet; he ultimately resigned his position in December 1793 DATE , and Washington GPE forsook him.[267]
The feud led to the well-defined Federalist NORP and Republican NORP parties, and party affiliation became necessary for election to Congress ORG by 1794.[268 CARDINAL ] Washington GPE remained aloof from congressional attacks on Hamilton PERSON , but did not publicly protect him. The Hamilton PERSON Reynolds ORG sex scandal opened Hamilton PERSON to disgrace, but Washington GPE continued to hold him in "very high esteem".[269]
In March 1791 DATE , at Hamilton PERSON 's urging, with support from Madison PERSON , Congress ORG imposed an excise tax on distilled spirits to help curtail the national debt, which took effect in July.[270] Grain farmers strongly protested in Pennsylvania GPE 's frontier districts; they argued that they were unrepresented and were shouldering too much of the debt, comparing their situation to British NORP taxation pre-Revolution EVENT .
On August 2 DATE , Washington GPE assembled his cabinet to discuss the situation. Unlike Washington GPE , who had reservations about using force, Hamilton PERSON was eager to suppress the rebellion with federal authority.[271] Wanting to avoid involving the federal government, Washington GPE first ORDINAL called on Pennsylvania GPE state officials to take the initiative, but they declined. On August 7 DATE , Washington GPE issued his first ORDINAL proclamation for calling up state militias. After appealing for peace, he reminded the protestors that, unlike the rule of the British NORP crown, the Federal law was issued by state-elected representatives.[272]
Threats PRODUCT and violence against tax collectors, however, escalated into defiance against federal authority in 1794 DATE and gave rise to the Whiskey Rebellion ORG . Washington GPE issued a final proclamation on September 25 DATE , threatening the use of military force to no avail.[272] The federal army was not up to the task, so Washington GPE invoked the Militia Act LAW of 1792 DATE to summon state militias.[273] Governors sent troops, initially commanded by Washington GPE , who handed over command to Henry Lee PERSON to lead them into the rebellious districts. They took 150 CARDINAL prisoners, and the remaining rebels dispersed. Two CARDINAL of the prisoners were condemned to death, but Washington GPE exercised his Constitutional authority for the first ORDINAL time and pardoned them.[274]
Washington GPE 's forceful action demonstrated that the new government could protect itself and its tax collectors. This represented the first ORDINAL use of federal military force against the states and citizens.[275] Washington GPE justified his action against "certain self-created societies", which he regarded as "subversive organizations" that threatened the national union. He did not dispute their right to protest, but he insisted that their dissent must not violate federal law. Congress ORG agreed and extended their congratulations to him; only Madison PERSON and Jefferson PERSON expressed indifference.[276]
In April 1792 DATE , the French Revolutionary Wars ORG began between Britain GPE and France GPE , and Washington GPE declared America GPE 's neutrality. The revolutionary government of France GPE sent diplomat Edmond-Charles PERSON Genet to America GPE , and he was welcomed with great enthusiasm. He created a network of new Democratic NORP -Republican Societies promoting France GPE 's interests, but Washington GPE denounced them and demanded that the French NORP recall Genet.[277] The National Assembly of France ORG granted Washington GPE honorary French NORP citizenship on August 26, 1792 DATE , during the early stages of the French NORP Revolution.[278]
Hamilton PERSON formulated the Jay Treaty LAW to normalize trade relations with Britain GPE while removing them from western forts, and also to resolve financial debts remaining from the Revolution.[279] Chief Justice John Jay PERSON acted as Washington GPE 's negotiator and signed the treaty on November 19, 1794 DATE ; critical Jeffersonians PERSON , however, supported France GPE . Washington GPE deliberated, then supported the treaty because it avoided war with Britain,[280] but was disappointed that its provisions favored Britain.[281] He mobilized public opinion and secured ratification in the Senate[282 PERSON ] but faced frequent public criticism.[283]
The British NORP agreed to abandon their forts around the Great Lakes FAC , and the United States GPE modified the boundary with Canada GPE . The government liquidated numerous pre-Revolution EVENT debts, and the British NORP opened the British West Indies ORG to American NORP trade. The treaty secured peace with Britain GPE and a decade DATE of prosperous trade. Jefferson PERSON claimed that it angered France GPE and "invited rather than avoided" war.[284] Relations with France GPE deteriorated afterward and, two days DATE before Washington GPE 's term ended, the French Directory ORG declared the authority to seize American NORP ships,[285] leaving succeeding president John Adams PERSON with prospective war.[286]
Ron Chernow PERSON describes Washington GPE as always trying to be even-handed in dealing with the Natives ORG . He states that Washington GPE hoped they would abandon their itinerant hunting life and adapt to fixed agricultural communities in the manner of white settlers. He also maintains that Washington GPE never advocated outright confiscation of tribal land or the forcible removal of tribes and that he berated American NORP settlers who abused natives, admitting that he held out no hope for peaceful relations as long as "frontier settlers entertain the opinion that there is not the same crime (or indeed no crime at all) in killing a native as in killing a white man."[287]
By contrast, Colin G. Calloway PERSON wrote that, " Washington GPE had a lifelong obsession with getting Indian NORP land, either for himself or for his nation, and initiated policies and campaigns that had devastating effects in Indian NORP country."[288] He stated:
The growth of the nation demanded the dispossession of Indian NORP people. Washington GPE hoped the process could be bloodless and that Indian NORP people would give up their lands for a "fair" price and move away. But if Indians NORP refused and resisted, as they often did, he felt he had no choice but to "extirpate" them and that the expeditions he sent to destroy Indian NORP towns were therefore entirely justified.[289]During the fall of 1789 DATE , Washington GPE had to contend with the British NORP refusing to evacuate their forts in the Northwest ORG frontier and their concerted efforts to incite Indian NORP tribes to attack American NORP settlers.[290] The Northwest ORG tribes under Miami GPE chief Little Turtle PERSON allied with the British NORP to resist American NORP expansion, and killed 1,500 CARDINAL settlers between 1783 DATE and 1790.[291 CARDINAL ]
Washington GPE declared that " the Government of the United States WORK_OF_ART are determined that their Administration of Indian Affairs shall be directed entirely by the great principles of Justice ORG and humanity", and provided that treaties should negotiate their land interests.[292] The administration regarded powerful tribes as foreign nations, and Washington GPE even smoked a peace pipe and drank wine with them at the President's House ORG in Philadelphia.[293] He made numerous attempts to conciliate them;[294] he equated killing indigenous peoples with killing whites and sought to integrate them into European American NORP culture.[295]
In the Southwest LOC , negotiations failed between federal commissioners and raiding Indian NORP tribes seeking retribution. Washington GPE invited Creek GPE Chief Alexander McGillivray PERSON and 24 CARDINAL leading chiefs to New York GPE to negotiate a treaty and treated them like foreign dignitaries. Knox PERSON and McGillivray PERSON concluded the Treaty of New York GPE on August 7, 1790 DATE , which provided the tribes with agricultural supplies and McGillivray PERSON with the rank of Brigadier General ORG and an annual salary of $ 1,200 MONEY , equivalent to $ 28,404 MONEY in 2022.[296 CARDINAL ]
In 1790 DATE , Washington GPE sent Brigadier General Josiah Harmar PERSON to pacify the Northwest ORG tribes, but Little Turtle PERSON routed him twice and forced him to withdraw.[297] The Northwestern Confederacy of WORK_OF_ART tribes used guerrilla tactics and were an effective force against the sparsely manned American Army ORG . Washington GPE sent Major General Arthur St. Clair PERSON from Fort Washington FAC on an expedition to restore peace in the territory in 1791 DATE . On November 4 DATE , St. Clair's ORG forces were ambushed and soundly defeated by tribal forces with few survivors.[298]
Washington GPE replaced the disgraced St. Clair ORG with the Revolutionary War EVENT hero Anthony Wayne PERSON . From 1792 to 1793, Wayne PERSON instructed his troops on Native American NORP warfare tactics and instilled discipline which was lacking under St. Clair.[299] In August 1794 DATE , Washington GPE sent Wayne PERSON into tribal territory with authority to drive them out by burning their villages and crops in the Maumee Valley.[300] On August 24 DATE , the American NORP army defeated the Northwestern Confederacy ORG at the Battle of Fallen Timbers FAC , and the Treaty of Greenville PRODUCT in August 1795 DATE opened two-thirds CARDINAL of the Ohio Country ORG for American settlement.[301]
Washington GPE initially planned to retire after his first ORDINAL term, weary of office and in poor health. After dealing with the infighting in his own cabinet and with partisan critics, he showed little enthusiasm for a second ORDINAL term, while Martha PERSON also wanted him not to run.[302 ORG ] Washington GPE 's nephew George Augustine PERSON Washington GPE , managing Mount Vernon LOC in his absence, was critically ill, further increasing Washington GPE 's desire to retire.[303]
Many, however, urged him to run for a second ORDINAL term. Madison PERSON told him that his absence would only allow the dangerous political rift in his cabinet and the House ORG to worsen. Jefferson PERSON also pleaded with him not to retire, agreeing to drop his attacks on Hamilton PERSON , and stating that he would also retire if Washington GPE did.[304] Hamilton PERSON maintained that Washington GPE 's absence would be "deplored as the greatest evil" to the country.[305] With the election of 1792 DATE nearing, Washington GPE relented and agreed to run.[295]
On February 13, 1793 DATE , the Electoral College ORG unanimously re-elected Washington GPE president, and John Adams PERSON as vice president by a vote of 77 to 50.[295 CARDINAL ] He was sworn into office by Associate Justice William Cushing ORG on March 4, 1793 DATE , in the Senate Chamber of Congress Hall ORG in Philadelphia GPE . Afterwards, Washington GPE gave a brief address before immediately retiring to the President's House.[306]
On April 22, 1793 DATE , when the French NORP Revolutionary Wars broke out, Washington GPE issued a proclamation which declared American NORP neutrality. He was resolved to pursue "a conduct friendly and impartial toward the belligerent Powers ORG " while also warning Americans NORP not to intervene in the conflict.[307] Although Washington GPE recognized France GPE 's revolutionary government, he would eventually ask French NORP minister to the United States GPE Edmond-Charles PERSON Genet be recalled over the Citizen Genet affair.[308] Genet was a diplomatic troublemaker who was openly hostile toward Washington GPE 's neutrality policy. He procured four CARDINAL American NORP ships as privateers to strike at Spanish NORP forces ( British NORP allies) in Florida GPE while organizing militias to strike at other British NORP possessions. However, his efforts failed to draw the United States GPE into the conflict.[309]
On July 31, 1793 DATE , Jefferson PERSON submitted his resignation from cabinet.[310] Hamilton PERSON , desiring more income for his family, resigned from office in January 1795 DATE and was replaced by Oliver Wolcott Jr PERSON .. While his relationship with Washington GPE would remain friendly, Washington GPE 's relationship with his Secretary of War Henry Knox PERSON deteriorated after rumors that Knox ORG had profited from contracts for the construction of U.S. GPE frigates which had been commissioned under the Naval Act of 1794 LAW in order to combat Barbary PERSON pirates, forcing Knox PERSON to resign.[311][312]
In the final months DATE of his presidency, Washington GPE was assailed by his political foes and a partisan press who accused him of being ambitious and greedy. He came to regard the press as a disuniting, "diabolical" force of falsehoods.[313] At the end of his second ORDINAL term, Washington GPE retired for personal and political reasons, dismayed with personal attacks, and to ensure that a truly contested presidential election could be held. He did not feel bound to a two CARDINAL -term limit, but his retirement set a significant precedent.[314]
In 1796 DATE , Washington GPE declined to run for a third ORDINAL term of office.[315] In May 1792 DATE , in anticipation of his retirement, Washington GPE instructed James Madison PERSON to prepare a "valedictory address", an initial draft of which was entitled the "Farewell Address".[316] In May 1796 DATE , Washington GPE sent the manuscript to Alexander Hamilton PERSON who did an extensive rewrite, while Washington GPE provided final edits.[317] On September 19, 1796 DATE , David Claypoole's PERSON American Daily Advertiser ORG published the final version.[318]
Washington GPE stressed that national identity was paramount, as a united America GPE would safeguard freedom and prosperity. He warned the nation of three CARDINAL eminent dangers: regionalism, partisanship, and foreign entanglements, and said the "name of AMERICAN ORG , which belongs to you, in your national capacity, must always exalt the just pride of patriotism".[319] Washington GPE called for men to move beyond partisanship for the common good, stressing that the United States GPE must concentrate on its own interests. He warned against foreign alliances and their influence in domestic affairs, and bitter partisanship and the dangers of political parties.[320] He counseled friendship and commerce with all nations, but advised against involvement in European NORP wars.[321] He stressed the importance of religion, asserting that "religion and morality are indispensable supports" in a republic.[322 NORP ] Washington GPE 's address favored Hamilton PERSON 's Federalist NORP ideology and economic policies.[323]
He closed the address by reflecting on his legacy:
Though in reviewing the incidents of my Administration I am unconscious of intentional error, I am nevertheless too sensible of my defects not to think it probable that I may have committed many errors. Whatever they may be, I fervently beseech the Almighty to avert or mitigate the evils to which they may tend. I shall also carry with me the hope that my country will never cease to view them with indulgence, and that, after forty-five years DATE of my life dedicated to its service with an upright zeal, the faults of incompetent abilities will be consigned to oblivion, as myself must soon be to the mansions of rest.[324]After initial publication, many Republicans NORP , including Madison PERSON , criticized the Address ORG and described it as an anti-French NORP campaign document, with Madison PERSON believing that Washington GPE was strongly pro-British.[325]
In 1839 DATE , Washington GPE biographer Jared Sparks ORG maintained that Washington GPE 's " Farewell Address WORK_OF_ART was printed and published with the laws, by order of the legislatures, as an evidence of the value they attached to its political precepts, and of their affection for its author."[326] In 1972 DATE , Washington GPE scholar James Flexner PERSON referred to the Farewell Address ORG as receiving as much acclaim as Thomas Jefferson's PERSON Declaration of Independence and Abraham Lincoln's PERSON Gettysburg Address.[327] GPE In 2010 DATE , historian Ron Chernow PERSON called the Farewell Address one of the most influential statements on republicanism.[328]
Washington GPE retired to Mount Vernon GPE in March 1797 DATE and devoted time to his plantations and other business interests.[329] His plantation operations were only minimally profitable,[31] and his lands in the west ( Piedmont GPE ) were under Indian NORP attacks and yielded little income, with squatters there refusing to pay rent. He attempted to sell these but without success.[330] He became an even more committed Federalist NORP . He vocally supported the Alien and Sedition Acts and convinced Federalist NORP John Marshall PERSON to run for Congress ORG to weaken the Jeffersonian NORP hold on Virginia.[331]
Washington GPE grew restless in retirement, prompted by tensions with France GPE ; in a continuation of the French Revolutionary Wars ORG , French NORP privateers began seizing American NORP ships in 1798 DATE , and relations deteriorated with France GPE and led to the "Quasi-War WORK_OF_ART ". Washington GPE wrote to Secretary of War James McHenry PERSON offering to organize President Adams' PERSON army.[332] PERSON Adams nominated him for a lieutenant general commission on July 4, 1798 DATE , and the position of commander-in-chief of the armies.[333] Washington GPE served as the commanding general from July 13, 1798 DATE , until his death 17 months DATE later.[334] He participated in planning for a provisional army, but avoided involvement in details. In advising McHenry ORG of potential officers for the army, he appeared to make a complete break with Jefferson's ORG Democratic-Republicans NORP : "you could as soon scrub the blackamoor white, as to change the principles of a profest Democrat NORP ; and that he will leave nothing unattempted to overturn the government of this country."[335] Washington GPE delegated the active leadership of the army to Hamilton PERSON , a major general. No army invaded the United States GPE during this period, and Washington GPE did not assume a field command.[336]
Washington GPE was known to be rich because of the well-known "glorified facade of wealth and grandeur" at Mount Vernon,[337 GPE ] but nearly all his wealth was in the form of land and slaves rather than ready cash. To supplement his income, he erected a distillery for substantial whiskey production.[338] He bought land parcels to spur development around the new Federal City ORG named in his honor, and he sold individual lots to middle-income investors rather than multiple lots to large investors, believing they would more likely commit to making improvements.[339]
On December 12, 1799 DATE , Washington GPE inspected his farms on horseback. He returned home late and had guests for dinner. He had a sore throat the next day DATE but was well enough to mark trees for cutting. That evening TIME , Washington GPE complained of chest congestion.[340] The next morning, however, he awoke to an inflamed throat and difficulty breathing. He ordered estate overseer George Rawlins PERSON to remove nearly a pint of his blood; bloodletting was a common practice of the time. His family summoned doctors James Craik PERSON , Gustavus Richard Brown PERSON , and Elisha C. Dick.[341 PERSON ] A fourth ORDINAL doctor, William Thornton PERSON , arrived some hours TIME after Washington GPE died.[342]
Brown PERSON initially believed Washington GPE had quinsy; Dick PERSON thought the condition was a more serious "violent inflammation of the throat".[343] They continued the process of bloodletting to approximately five CARDINAL pints, but Washington GPE 's condition deteriorated further. Dick PERSON proposed a tracheotomy, but the other physicians were not familiar with that procedure and disapproved.[344 ORG ] Washington GPE instructed Brown PERSON and Dick PERSON to leave the room, while he assured Craik ORG , "Doctor, I die hard, but I am not afraid to go."[345]
Washington GPE 's death came more swiftly than expected.[346] On his deathbed, out of fear of being entombed alive, he instructed his private secretary Tobias Lear PERSON to wait three days DATE before his burial.[347] According to Lear GPE , Washington GPE died between 10 p.m. and 11 p.m. TIME on December 14, 1799 DATE , with Martha PERSON seated at the foot of his bed. His last words were "'Tis well", from his conversation with Lear PERSON about his burial. He was 67.[348 CARDINAL ]
Congress ORG immediately adjourned for the day DATE upon news of Washington GPE 's death, and the Speaker's chair was shroud in black the next morning.[349] The funeral was held four days DATE after his death on December 18, 1799 DATE , at Mount Vernon GPE , where his body was interred. Cavalry and foot soldiers led the procession, and six CARDINAL colonels served as the pallbearers. The Mount Vernon funeral service was restricted mostly to family and friends.[350] Reverend Thomas Davis PERSON read the funeral service by the vault with a brief address, followed by a ceremony performed by members of Washington GPE 's Masonic ORG lodge in Alexandria GPE , Virginia.[351] Word of his death traveled slowly; church bells rang in the cities, and many businesses closed.[352] Memorial processions were held in major cities of the United States GPE . Martha PERSON wore a black mourning cape for one year DATE , and she burned their correspondence to protect their privacy. Only five CARDINAL letters between the couple are known to have survived: two CARDINAL from Martha PERSON to George PERSON and three CARDINAL from him to her.[353]
The diagnosis of Washington GPE 's illness and the immediate cause of his death have been subjects of debate since his death. The published account of doctors Craik ORG and Brown PERSON stated that his symptoms were consistent with cynanche trachealis, a term then used to describe severe inflammation of the upper windpipe, including quinsy.[l] Accusations have persisted since Washington GPE 's death concerning medical malpractice.[344] Modern medical authors have concluded that he likely died from severe epiglottitis complicated by the treatments, including multiple doses of calomel, a purgative, and extensive bloodletting which almost certainly caused hypovolemic shock.[m]
Washington GPE was buried in the old Washington GPE family vault at Mount Vernon LOC . At the time of his death, his estate was worth an estimated $780,000 MONEY in 1799 DATE , equivalent to $13.72 million MONEY in 2022.[359 CARDINAL ] Washington GPE 's peak net worth was $587 million MONEY , including 300 CARDINAL slaves.[360] Washington GPE held title to more than 65,000 acres QUANTITY of land in 37 CARDINAL different locations.[72]
In 1830 DATE , a disgruntled ex-employee of the estate attempted to steal what he thought was Washington GPE 's skull, prompting the construction of a more secure vault.[361] In his will, Washington GPE had left instructions for the construction of a new vault as the old family vault was crumbling and needed repair even before his death.[352] A new vault was constructed at Mount Vernon LOC the following year DATE to receive the remains of George PERSON and Martha PERSON and other relatives.[362]
In 1832 DATE , a joint Congressional NORP committee debated moving his body from Mount Vernon LOC to a crypt in the Capitol FAC . The crypt had been built by architect Charles Bulfinch PERSON in the 1820s DATE during the reconstruction of the burned-out capital, after the Burning of Washington FAC by the British NORP during the War of 1812 EVENT . Southern NORP opposition was intense, antagonized by an ever-growing rift between North GPE and South LOC ; many were concerned that Washington GPE 's remains could end up on "a shore foreign to his native soil" if the country became divided, and Washington GPE 's remains stayed in Mount Vernon.[363 LOC ]
On October 7, 1837 DATE , Washington GPE 's remains, still in the original lead coffin, were placed within a marble sarcophagus designed by William Strickland PERSON and constructed by John Struthers.[364] PERSON The sarcophagus was sealed and encased with planks, and an outer vault was constructed around it.[365] The outer vault has the sarcophagi of both George PERSON and Martha Washington PERSON ; the inner vault has the remains of other Washington GPE family members and relatives.[362]
Washington GPE was somewhat reserved in personality, but was known for having a strong presence. He made speeches and announcements when required, but he was not a noted orator or debater.[366] He was taller than most of his contemporaries;[367] accounts of his height vary from 6 ft ( QUANTITY 1.83 CARDINAL m) to 6 CARDINAL ft 3.5 CARDINAL in ( 1.92 CARDINAL m) tall,[64][368] he weighed between 210220 pounds QUANTITY ( 95100 kg QUANTITY ) as an adult,[369] and was known for his great strength.[370]
He had grey-blue eyes and long reddish-brown hair. He did not wear a powdered wig; instead he wore his hair curled, powdered, and tied in a queue in the fashion of the day.[371][372]
Washington GPE frequently suffered from severe tooth decay and ultimately lost all his teeth but one. He had several sets of false teeth during his presidency. Contrary to common lore, these were not made of wood, but of metal, ivory, bone, animal teeth, and human teeth possibly obtained from slaves.[373] These dental problems left him in constant pain, which he treated with laudanum.[374]
Washington GPE was a talented equestrian, with Thomas Jefferson PERSON describing him as "the best horseman of his age".[375] He collected thoroughbreds at Mount Vernon LOC , his two CARDINAL favorite horses being Blueskin PERSON and Nelson.[376] He enjoyed hunting foxes, deer, ducks, and other game.[377] He was an excellent dancer and frequently attended the theater. He drank alcohol in moderation but was morally opposed to excessive drinking, smoking tobacco, gambling, and profanity.[378]
Washington GPE was descended from Anglican NORP minister Lawrence Washington PERSON , whose troubles with the Church of England ORG may have prompted his heirs to emigrate to America.[379] He was baptized as an infant in April 1732 DATE and became a devoted member of the Anglican NORP Church.[380] He served more than 20 years DATE as a vestryman and churchwarden at Fairfax GPE Parish NORP and Truco Parish PERSON in Virginia.[381] He privately prayed and read the Bible WORK_OF_ART daily DATE , and publicly encouraged people and the nation to pray.[382] He may have taken communion on a regular basis prior to the Revolution EVENT , but he did not do so following the war.[383]
Washington GPE believed in a "wise, inscrutable, and irresistible" Creator God who was active in the Universe ORG , contrary to deistic thought.[379] He referred to God in Enlightenment terms, including Providence PERSON , the Creator, or the Almighty, and the Divine Author or Supreme ORG Being.[384] He believed in a divine power who watched over battlefields, was involved in the outcome of war, protected his life, and was involved in American NORP politics and specifically the creation of the United States.[n][386] Historian Ron Chernow PERSON has argued that Washington GPE avoided evangelistic Christianity NORP or hellfire-and-brimstone speech along with communion or anything inclined to "flaunt his religiosity", saying that he "never used his religion as a device for partisan purposes or in official undertakings".[387] No mention of Jesus Christ PERSON appears in his private correspondence, and such references are rare in his public writings.[388] At the same time, Washington GPE frequently quoted from the Bible WORK_OF_ART or paraphrased it, and often referred to the Anglican Book of Common ORG Prayer.[389]
Washington GPE emphasized religious toleration in a nation with numerous denominations and religions. He publicly attended services of different Christian NORP denominations and prohibited anti-Catholic NORP celebrations in the Army.[390] He engaged workers at Mount Vernon LOC without regard for religious belief or affiliation. While president, he acknowledged major religious sects and gave speeches on religious toleration.[391] He was distinctly rooted in the ideas, values, and modes of thinking of the Enlightenment,[392] but he harbored no contempt of organized Christianity NORP and its clergy, "being no bigot myself to any mode of worship".[392] In 1793 DATE , speaking to members of the New Church ORG in Baltimore GPE , Washington GPE said, "We have abundant reason to rejoice that in this Land the light of truth and reason has triumphed over the power of bigotry and superstition."[393]
Freemasonry WORK_OF_ART was a widely accepted institution in the late 18th century DATE , known for advocating moral teachings.[394] Washington GPE was attracted to the Masons ORG ' dedication to the Enlightenment principles of rationality, reason, and brotherhood. American NORP Masonic lodges did not share the anti-clerical views of the controversial European NORP lodges.[395]
A Masonic NORP lodge was established in Fredericksburg GPE , Virginia GPE in September 1752 DATE , and Washington GPE was initiated two months later DATE at the age of 20 DATE as one of its first Entered Apprentices ORG . Within a year DATE , he progressed through its ranks to become a Master Mason.[396] Washington GPE had high regard for the Masonic Order ORG , but his lodge attendance was sporadic. In 1777 DATE , a convention of Virginia GPE lodges asked him to be the Grand Master of the newly established Grand Lodge FAC of Virginia GPE , but he declined due to his commitments leading the Continental Army ORG . After 1782 DATE , he frequently corresponded with Masonic NORP lodges and members,[397] and he was listed as Master in the Virginia GPE charter of Alexandria Lodge PERSON No. 22 CARDINAL in 1788.[398]
In Washington GPE 's lifetime, slavery was deeply ingrained in the economic and social fabric of the Colony of Virginia GPE , which continued after the Revolution EVENT and the establishment of Virginia GPE as a state.[399][400] Slavery was legal in all of the Thirteen CARDINAL Colonies ORG prior to the American NORP Revolution.[401]
Washington GPE owned and rented enslaved African Americans NORP , and during his lifetime over 577 slaves lived and worked at Mount Vernon.[402][403 LOC ] He acquired them through inheritance, gaining control of 84 CARDINAL dower slaves upon his marriage to Martha PERSON , and purchased at least 71 CARDINAL slaves between 1752 DATE and 1773.[404 CARDINAL ] From 1786 DATE , he rented slaves; at the time of his death he was renting 41.[405][402 CARDINAL ]
Prior to the Revolutionary War EVENT , Washington GPE 's view on slavery was the same as most Virginia GPE planters of the time.[406] Beginning in the 1760s DATE , however, Washington GPE gradually grew to oppose it. His first ORDINAL doubts were prompted by his transition from tobacco to grain crops, which left him with a costly surplus of slaves, causing him to question the system's economic efficiency.[407] His growing disillusionment with the institution was spurred by the principles of the Revolution EVENT and revolutionary friends such as Lafayette ORG and Hamilton.[408] Most historians agree the Revolution EVENT was central to the evolution of Washington GPE 's attitudes on slavery;[409] "After 1783 DATE ," Kenneth Morgan PERSON writes, "... [ Washington GPE ] began to express inner tensions about the problem of slavery more frequently, though always in private".[410] Regardless, Washington GPE would remain dependent on slave labor to work his farms.[411]
The many contemporary reports of slave treatment at Mount Vernon LOC are varied and conflicting.[412] Historian Kenneth Morgan PERSON maintains that Washington GPE was frugal on spending for clothes and bedding for his slaves, and only provided them with just enough food, and that he maintained strict control over his slaves, instructing his overseers to keep them working hard from dawn to dusk year-round.[413 DATE ] In contrast, historian Dorothy Twohig PERSON said: "Food, clothing, and housing seem to have been at least adequate".[414]
Washington GPE faced growing debts involved with the costs of supporting slaves. He held an "engrained sense of racial superiority" towards African Americans NORP but harbored no ill feelings toward them.[415] Some enslaved families worked at different locations on the plantation but were allowed to visit one another on their days off.[416] Washington GPE 's slaves received two hours TIME off for meals during the workday and were given time off on Sundays DATE and religious holidays.[417][418]
Some accounts report that Washington GPE opposed flogging but at times sanctioned its use, generally as a last resort, on both men and women slaves.[419] Washington GPE used both reward and punishment to encourage discipline and productivity in his slaves. He tried appealing to an individual's sense of pride, gave better blankets and clothing to the "most deserving", and motivated his slaves with cash rewards. He believed "watchfulness and admonition" were better deterrents against transgressions but would punish those who "will not do their duty by fair means". Punishment ranged in severity from demotion back to fieldwork, through whipping and beatings, to permanent separation from friends and family by sale. Historian Ron Chernow PERSON maintains that overseers were required to warn slaves before resorting to the lash and required Washington GPE 's written permission before whipping, though his extended absences did not always permit this.[420]
During his presidency, Washington GPE brought several of his slaves to the federal capital. When the capital moved from New York City GPE to Philadelphia GPE in 1791 DATE , the president began rotating his slave household staff periodically between the capital and Mount Vernon LOC . This was done deliberately to circumvent Pennsylvania GPE 's Slavery Abolition Act ORG , which stated that any slave who lived there for more than six months DATE was automatically freed.[421]
In May 1796 DATE , Martha PERSON 's personal and favorite slave Ona Judge escaped to Portsmouth ORG , New Hampshire GPE . At Martha PERSON 's behest, Washington GPE attempted to capture Ona PERSON , using a Treasury ORG agent, but failed. In February 1797 DATE , around the time of his 65th ORDINAL birthday, Washington GPE 's personal slave Hercules Posey PERSON escaped from Mount Vernon GPE to Philadelphia GPE and was never found.[422]
In February 1786 DATE , Washington GPE took a census of Mount Vernon GPE and recorded 224 CARDINAL slaves.[423] By 1799 DATE , the slave population at Mount Vernon LOC totaled 317 CARDINAL , including 143 CARDINAL children.[424 PERSON ] Washington GPE owned 124 CARDINAL slaves, leased 40 CARDINAL , and held 153 CARDINAL for his wife's dower interest.[425][6] Washington GPE supported many slaves who were too young or too old to work, greatly increasing Mount Vernon's LOC slave population and causing the plantation to operate at a loss.[426]
Based on his private papers and on accounts from his contemporaries, Washington GPE slowly developed a cautious sympathy toward abolitionism that eventually ended with his will freeing his long-time valet Billy Lee PERSON , and then subsequently freeing the rest of his personally owned slaves outright upon Martha PERSON 's death.[427][428 ORG ] As president, he remained publicly silent on the topic of slavery, believing it was a nationally divisive issue that could undermine the union.[429]
During the Revolutionary War EVENT , Washington GPE 's views on slavery began to change.[401] In a 1778 DATE letter to Lund Washington GPE , he made clear his desire "to get quit of Negroes ORG " when discussing the exchange of slaves for the land he wanted to buy.[430 PERSON ] The next year DATE , Washington GPE stated his intention not to separate enslaved families as a result of "a change of masters".[431] During the 1780s DATE , Washington GPE privately expressed his support for gradual emancipation.[432] In the 1780s DATE , he gave moral support to a plan proposed by Lafayette ORG to purchase land and free slaves to work on it, but declined to participate in the experiment.[414]
Washington GPE privately expressed support for emancipation to prominent Methodists Thomas Coke LOC and Francis Asbury PERSON in 1785 DATE but declined to sign their petition.[433] In personal correspondence the next year DATE , he made clear his desire to see the institution of slavery ended by a gradual legislative process, a view that correlated with the mainstream antislavery literature published in the 1780s DATE that Washington GPE possessed.[434] He significantly reduced his purchases of slaves after the war but continued to acquire them in small numbers.[435]
In 1788 DATE , Washington GPE declined a suggestion from a leading French NORP abolitionist, Jacques Brissot PERSON , to establish an abolitionist society in Virginia GPE , stating that although he supported the idea, the time was not yet right.[436] Historian Philip D. Morgan PERSON wrote that Washington GPE was determined not to risk national unity.[437] Washington GPE never responded to any of the antislavery petitions he received, and the subject was not mentioned in either his last address to Congress ORG or his Farewell Address.[438]
The first ORDINAL clear indication that Washington GPE seriously intended to free his slaves appears in a letter written to his secretary, Tobias Lear PERSON , in 1794.[439 CARDINAL ] Washington GPE instructed Lear to find buyers for his land in western Virginia GPE , explaining in a private coda that he was doing so "to liberate a certain species of property which I possess, very repugnantly to my own feelings".[440] The plan, along with others Washington GPE considered in 1795 DATE and 1796 DATE , could not be realized because he failed to find buyers for his land, his reluctance to break up slave families, and the refusal of the Custis PRODUCT heirs to help prevent such separations by freeing their dower slaves at the same time.[441]
On July 9, 1799 DATE , Washington GPE finished making his last will; the longest provision concerned slavery. All his slaves were to be freed after the death of his wife. Washington ORG said he did not free them immediately because his slaves intermarried with his wife's dower slaves. He forbade their sale or transportation out of Virginia GPE . The provision also provided that old and young freed people be taken care of indefinitely; younger ones were to be taught to read and write and placed in suitable occupations.[442] PERSON Washington GPE emancipated 123 CARDINAL slaves, one CARDINAL of the few large slave-holding Virginians NORP during the Revolutionary Era ORG to do so.[443][444]
On January 1, 1801 DATE , one year DATE after George Washington's PERSON death, Martha Washington PERSON signed an order to free his slaves. Many of them, having never strayed far from Mount Vernon GPE , were reluctant to leave; others refused to abandon spouses or children still held as dower slaves by the Custis PRODUCT estate and also stayed with or near Martha.[445] Following Washington GPE 's instructions in his will, funds were used to feed and clothe the young, aged, and infirm slaves until the early 1830s.[446 ORG ]
Washington GPE 's legacy endures as one CARDINAL of the most influential in American NORP history since he served as commander-in-chief of the Continental Army ORG , a hero of the Revolution EVENT , and the first ORDINAL president of the United States GPE . Various historians maintain that he also was a dominant factor in America GPE 's founding.[447] Revolutionary War FAC comrade Henry Lee PERSON eulogized him as " First ORDINAL in war, first ORDINAL in peace, and first ORDINAL in the hearts of his countrymen".[448] Lee PERSON 's words became the hallmark by which Washington GPE 's reputation was impressed upon the American NORP memory, with some biographers regarding him as the great exemplar of republicanism. He set many precedents for the national government and the presidency in particular, and he was called the " Father of His Country WORK_OF_ART " as early as 1778.[o][450][451 CARDINAL ]
Washington GPE became an international symbol for liberation and nationalism as the leader of the first ORDINAL successful revolution against a colonial empire. The Federalists NORP made him the symbol of their party, but the Jeffersonians NORP continued to distrust his influence for years DATE and delayed building the Washington GPE Monument.[452] Washington GPE was elected a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences ORG on January 31 DATE , 1781.[453 CARDINAL ]
In 1879 DATE , Congress ORG proclaimed Washington GPE 's Birthday to be a federal holiday.[454] Through a congressional joint resolution Public Law 94 CARDINAL -479, passed on January 19, 1976 DATE , with an effective appointment date of July 4, 1976 DATE , he was posthumously appointed to the grade of General of the Armies of the United States ORG during the American Bicentennial EVENT . President Gerald Ford PERSON stated that Washington GPE would "rank first ORDINAL among all officers of the Army ORG , past and present".[p][456] On March 13, 1978 DATE , Washington GPE was militarily promoted to the rank of General of the Armies.[457]
In 1809 DATE , Mason Locke Weems ORG wrote a hagiographic biography to honor Washington.[458] Historian Ron Chernow PERSON maintains that Weems ORG attempted to humanize Washington GPE , making him look less stern, and to inspire "patriotism and morality" and to foster "enduring myths", such as Washington GPE 's refusal to lie about damaging his father's cherry tree.[459][460] Weems' accounts have never been proven or disproven.[461] Historian John Ferling PERSON , however, maintains that Washington GPE remains the only founder and president ever to be referred to as "godlike", and points out that his character has been the most scrutinized by historians.[462] Biographer Douglas Southall Freeman PERSON concluded, "The great big thing stamped across that man is character." Expanding on Freeman PERSON 's assessment, historian David Hackett Fischer PERSON defined Washington GPE 's character as "integrity, self-discipline, courage, absolute honesty, resolve, and decision, but also forbearance, decency, and respect for others".[463]
In the 21st century DATE , Washington GPE 's reputation has been critically scrutinized. Along with other Founding Fathers, he has been condemned for holding enslaved people. Though he expressed the desire to see the abolition of slavery come through legislation, he did not initiate or support any initiatives for bringing about its end. This has led to calls from some activists to remove his name from public buildings and his statue from public spaces.[464] Nonetheless, Washington GPE maintains his place among the highest-ranked U.S. GPE Presidents.[465]
Many places and monuments have been named in honor of Washington GPE , most notably Washington GPE , D.C. GPE , the capital of the United States GPE , and the state of Washington GPE , the only U.S. GPE state to be named after a president.[466]
On February 21, 1885 DATE , the Washington Monument ORG was dedicated. The 555-foot QUANTITY marble obelisk, which stands on the National Mall PRODUCT in Washington GPE , D.C. GPE , was built between 18481854 and 18791884 DATE and was the tallest structure in the world between 1884 DATE and 1889.[467 DATE ]
Washington GPE appears as one CARDINAL of four CARDINAL U.S. GPE presidents on the Shrine of Democracy WORK_OF_ART , a colossal statue by Gutzon Borglum PERSON on Mount Rushmore LOC in South LOC Dakota.[468]
A number of secondary schools and universities are named in honor of Washington GPE , including George Washington University ORG and Washington University ORG in St. Louis.[469][470]
Washington GPE appears on contemporary U.S. GPE currency, including the one-dollar MONEY bill, the Presidential one-dollar MONEY coin and the quarter-dollar MONEY coin ( the Washington quarter DATE ). Washington GPE and Benjamin Franklin PERSON appeared on the nation's first ORDINAL postage stamps in 1847 DATE . Washington GPE has since appeared on many postage issues, more than any other person.[471]
In [31]:
# Task 2.1
def make_redacted(txt):
    doc = nlp(txt)
    result = []
    for token in doc:
        if token.ent_type_ == 'PERSON':
            result.append("[REDACTED]")
        else:
            result.append(token.text)  # Use token.text instead of token.string
    return " ".join(result)

redacted_text = make_redacted(content)
print(redacted_text)

 [REDACTED] [REDACTED] ( February 22 , 1732  December 14 , 1799 ) was an American military officer , statesman , and Founding Father who served as the first president of the United States from 1789 to 1797 . Appointed by the Second Continental Congress as commander of the Continental Army in June 1775 , Washington led Patriot forces to victory in the American Revolutionary War and then served as president of the Constitutional Convention in 1787 , which drafted and ratified the Constitution of the United States and established the American federal government . Washington has thus been called the " Father of his Country " . 
 Washington 's first public office , from 1749 to 1750 , was as surveyor of Culpeper County in the Colony of Virginia . He subsequently received military training and was assigned command of the Virginia Regiment during the French and Indian War . He was later elected to the Virginia House of Burgesses and was named a delegate to the Continental Congress in Philadelphia , which appointed him Commander - in - Chief of the Continental Army . Washington led American forces to a decisive victory over the British in the Revolutionary War , leading the British to sign the Treaty of Paris , which acknowledged the sovereignty and independence of the United States . He resigned his commission in 1783 after the conclusion of the Revolutionary War . 
 Washington played an indispensable role in adopting and ratifying the Constitution , which replaced the Articles of Confederation in 1789 . He was then twice elected president by the Electoral College unanimously . As the first U.S. president , Washington implemented a strong , well - financed national government while remaining impartial in a fierce rivalry that emerged between cabinet members [REDACTED] [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] . During the French Revolution , he proclaimed a policy of neutrality while sanctioning the Jay Treaty . He set enduring precedents for the office of president , including use of the title " Mr. President " and the two - term tradition . His 1796 farewell address became a preeminent statement on republicanism in which he wrote about the importance of national unity and the dangers regionalism , partisanship , and foreign influence pose to it . 
 Washington has been memorialized by monuments , a federal holiday , various media depictions , geographical locations including the national capital , the State of Washington , stamps , and currency . He is ranked among the greatest U.S. presidents . In 1976 , Washington was posthumously promoted to the rank of General of the Armies , the highest rank in the U.S. Army . His legacy is marred , however , by his ownership of slaves and his complicated relationship with slavery , as well as his policy to assimilate Native Americans into the Anglo - American culture and waging war against Native American nations during the Revolutionary Wars and the Northwest Indian War . 
 [REDACTED] [REDACTED] was born on February 22 , 1732,[a ] at Popes Creek in Westmoreland County , Virginia.[3 ] He was the first of six children of [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] ] His father was a justice of the peace and a prominent public figure who had four additional children from his first marriage to [REDACTED] [REDACTED] ] The family moved to Little Hunting Creek in 1734 before eventually settling in Ferry Farm near Fredericksburg , Virginia . When [REDACTED] died in 1743 , Washington inherited Ferry Farm and ten slaves ; his older half - brother [REDACTED] inherited [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] and renamed it Mount Vernon.[6][7 ] 
 Washington did not have the formal education his elder brothers received at Appleby Grammar School in England , but he did attend the Lower Church School in Hartfield . He learned mathematics , trigonometry , and land surveying , and became a talented draftsman and mapmaker . By early adulthood , he was writing with " considerable force " and " precision".[8 ] As a teenager , to practice his penmanship , Washington compiled over a hundred rules for social interaction styled Rules of Civility and Decent Behaviour in Company and Conversation , copied from an English translation of a French book of manners.[9 ] 
 Washington often visited Mount Vernon and Belvoir , the plantation of [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , [REDACTED] 's father - in - law . Fairfax became Washington 's patron and surrogate father , and Washington spent a month in 1748 with a team surveying Fairfax 's Shenandoah Valley property.[10 ] The following year , he received a surveyor 's license from the College of William & Mary.[b ] Even though Washington had not served the customary apprenticeship , Fairfax appointed him surveyor of Culpeper County , Virginia , where he took his oath of office July 20 , 1749 . He subsequently familiarized himself with the frontier region , and though he resigned from the job in 1750 , he continued to do surveys west of the Blue Ridge Mountains.[11 ] By 1752 , he had bought almost 1,500 acres ( 600 ha ) in the Valley and owned 2,315 acres ( 937 ha).[12 ] 
 In 1751 , Washington made his only trip abroad when he accompanied [REDACTED] to Barbados , hoping the climate would cure his brother 's tuberculosis.[13 ] Washington contracted smallpox during that trip , which left his face slightly scarred.[14 ] [REDACTED] died in 1752 , and Washington leased Mount Vernon from his widow [REDACTED] ; he inherited it outright after her death in 1761.[15 ] 
 [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] service as adjutant general of the Virginia militia inspired [REDACTED] to seek a commission . Virginia 's lieutenant governor , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , appointed Washington as a major and commander of one of the four militia districts . The British and French were competing for control of the Ohio Valley : the British were constructing forts along the Ohio River , and the French between the Ohio River and Lake Erie.[16 ] 
 In October 1753 , Dinwiddie appointed Washington as a special envoy . He had sent Washington to demand French forces to vacate land that was claimed by the British . Washington was also appointed to make peace with the Iroquois Confederacy , and to gather further intelligence about the French forces.[17 ] Washington met with Half - King Tanacharison , and other Iroquois chiefs , at Logstown , and gathered information about the numbers and locations of the French forts , as well as intelligence concerning individuals taken prisoner by the French . Washington was nicknamed Conotocaurius by Tanacharison . The name , meaning " devourer of villages " , had been given to his great - grandfather [REDACTED] [REDACTED] in the late 17th century by the Susquehannock.[18 ] 
 Washington 's party reached the Ohio River in November 1753 , and was intercepted by a French patrol . The party was escorted to Fort Le Boeuf , where Washington was received in a friendly manner . He delivered the British demand to vacate to the French commander [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , but the French refused to leave . [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] gave Washington his official answer after a few days ' delay , as well as food and winter clothing for his party 's journey back to Virginia.[19 ] Washington completed the precarious mission in 77 days , in difficult winter conditions , achieving a measure of distinction when his report was published in Virginia and London.[20 ] 
 In February 1754 , Dinwiddie promoted Washington to lieutenant colonel and second - in - command of the 300 - strong Virginia Regiment , with orders to confront French forces at the Forks of the Ohio.[21 ] Washington set out with half the regiment in April and soon learned a French force of 1,000 had begun construction of Fort Duquesne there . In May , having set up a defensive position at Great Meadows , he learned that the French had made camp seven miles ( 11 km ) away ; he decided to take the offensive.[22 ] 
 The French detachment proved to be only about 50 men , so Washington advanced on May 28 with a small force of Virginians and Indian allies to ambush them.[c][24 ] During the ambush , French forces were killed outright with muskets and hatchets , including French commander [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , who had been carrying a diplomatic message for the British . The French later found their countrymen dead and scalped and blamed Washington , who had retreated to Fort Necessity.[25 ] 
 The full Virginia Regiment joined Washington at Fort Necessity the following month with news that he had been promoted to command of the regiment and colonel upon the regimental commander 's death . The regiment was reinforced by an independent company of a hundred South Carolinians led by Captain [REDACTED] [REDACTED] ; his royal commission outranked Washington 's and a conflict of command ensued . On July 3 , a French force attacked with 900 men , and the ensuing battle ended in Washington 's surrender.[26 ] He signed a surrender document in which he unwittingly took responsibility for " assassinating " Jumonville , later blaming the translator for not properly translating it.[27 ] 
 In the aftermath , Colonel [REDACTED] [REDACTED] took command of intercolonial forces , the Virginia Regiment was divided , and Washington was offered a captaincy in one of the newly formed regiments . He refused , however , as it would have been a demotion and instead resigned his commission.[28 ] The " Jumonville affair " became the incident which ignited the French and Indian War , later to become part of the Seven Years ' War.[29][30 ] 
 In 1755 , Washington served voluntarily as an aide to General [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , who led a British expedition to expel the French from Fort Duquesne and the Ohio Country.[31 ] On Washington 's recommendation , [REDACTED] split the army into one main column and a lightly equipped " flying column".[32 ] Suffering from severe dysentery , Washington was left behind , and when he rejoined [REDACTED] at Monongahela the French and their Indian allies ambushed the divided army . Two - thirds of the British force became casualties , including the mortally wounded Braddock . Under the command of Lieutenant Colonel [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , Washington , still very ill , rallied the survivors and formed a rear guard , allowing the remnants of the force to disengage and retreat.[33 ] 
 During the engagement , he had two horses shot from under him , and his hat and coat were bullet - pierced.[34 ] His conduct under fire redeemed his reputation among critics of his command in the Battle of Fort Necessity,[35 ] but he was not included by the succeeding commander ( Colonel [REDACTED] [REDACTED] ) in planning subsequent operations.[36 ] 
 The Virginia Regiment was reconstituted in August 1755 , and Dinwiddie appointed Washington its commander , again with the rank of colonel . Washington clashed over seniority almost immediately , this time with [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , another captain of superior royal rank , who commanded a detachment of Marylanders at the regiment 's headquarters in Fort Cumberland.[37 ] Washington , impatient for an offensive against Fort Duquesne , was convinced Braddock would have granted him a royal commission and pressed his case in February 1756 with Braddock 's successor as Commander - in - Chief , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , and again in January 1757 with [REDACTED] 's successor , Lord Loudoun . [REDACTED] ruled in Washington 's favor only in the matter of Dagworthy ; Loudoun humiliated Washington , refused him a royal commission and agreed only to relieve him of the responsibility of manning Fort Cumberland.[38 ] 
 In 1758 , the Virginia Regiment was assigned to the British Forbes Expedition to capture Fort Duquesne.[d][40 ] Washington disagreed with General [REDACTED] [REDACTED] ' tactics and chosen route.[41 ] Forbes nevertheless made Washington a brevet brigadier general and gave him command of one of the three brigades that would assault the fort . The French had abandoned the fort and the valley before the assault , however , and Washington only saw a friendly fire incident which left 14 dead and 26 injured . Frustrated , he resigned his commission soon afterwards and returned to Mount Vernon.[42 ] 
 Under Washington , the Virginia Regiment had defended 300 miles ( 480 km ) of frontier against twenty Indian attacks in ten months.[43 ] He increased the professionalism of the regiment as it grew from 300 to 1,000 men , and Virginia 's frontier population suffered less than other colonies . Though he failed to realize a royal commission , he gained self - confidence , leadership skills , and knowledge of British military tactics . The destructive competition Washington witnessed among colonial politicians fostered his later support of a strong central government.[44 ] 
 On January 6 , 1759 , Washington , at age 26 , married [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , the 27 - year - old widow of wealthy plantation owner Daniel Parke Custis . The marriage took place at [REDACTED] 's estate ; she was intelligent , gracious , and experienced in managing a planter 's estate , and the couple had a happy marriage.[45 ] They moved to Mount Vernon , near Alexandria , where he lived as a planter of tobacco and wheat and emerged as a political figure.[46 ] 
 Washington 's 1751 bout with smallpox is thought to have rendered him sterile , though it is equally likely that " [REDACTED] may have sustained injury during the birth of [REDACTED] , her final child , making additional births impossible . "[47 ] The couple lamented not having any children together.[e][50 ] Despite this , the two raised [REDACTED] 's two children John Parke Custis ( [REDACTED] ) and Martha Parke Custis ( [REDACTED] ) , and later [REDACTED] 's two youngest children Eleanor Parke Custis ( Nelly ) and George Washington Parke Custis ( [REDACTED] ) , along with numerous nieces and nephews.[51 ] 
 The marriage gave Washington control over [REDACTED] 's one - third dower interest in the 18,000 - acre ( 7,300 ha ) Custis estate , and he managed the remaining two - thirds for [REDACTED] 's children ; the estate also included 84 slaves . As a result , he became one of the wealthiest men in Virginia , which increased his social standing.[52 ] 
 At Washington 's urging , Governor Lord Botetourt fulfilled Dinwiddie 's 1754 promise of land bounties to all - volunteer militia during the French and Indian War.[53 ] In late 1770 , Washington inspected the lands in the Ohio and Great Kanawha regions , and he engaged surveyor [REDACTED] [REDACTED] to subdivide it . Crawford allotted 23,200 acres ( 9,400 ha ) to Washington ; Washington told the veterans that their land was hilly and unsuitable for farming , and he agreed to purchase 20,147 acres ( 8,153 ha ) , leaving some feeling they had been duped.[54 ] He also doubled the size of Mount Vernon to 6,500 acres ( 2,600 ha ) and , by 1775 , had increased its slave population by more than a hundred.[55 ] 
 As a respected military hero and large landowner , Washington held local offices and was elected to the Virginia provincial legislature , representing Frederick County in the House of Burgesses for seven years beginning in 1758.[55 ] He first ran for the seat in 1755 but was soundly beaten by [REDACTED] West.[56][57 ] When he ran in 1758 , Washington plied voters with beer , brandy , and other beverages . Despite being away serving on the Forbes Expedition , he won the election with roughly 40 percent of the vote , defeating three opponents with the help of local supporters.[58][59 ] 
 Early in his legislative career , Washington rarely spoke or even attended legislative sessions . He would later become a prominent critic of Britain 's taxation policy and mercantilist policies towards the American colonies and became more politically active starting in the 1760s.[60 ] 
 Washington imported luxuries and other goods from England , paying for them by exporting tobacco . His profligate spending combined with low tobacco prices left him  1,800 in debt by 1764 , prompting him to diversify his holdings.[61 ] In 1765 , because of erosion and other soil problems , he changed [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] primary cash crop from tobacco to wheat and expanded operations to include corn flour milling and fishing.[62][63 ] 
 Washington soon was counted among the political and social elite in Virginia . From 1768 to 1775 , he invited some 2,000 guests to Mount Vernon , mostly those whom he considered people of rank , and was known to be exceptionally cordial toward guests.[64 ] Washington also took time for leisure with fox hunting , fishing , dances , theater , cards , backgammon , and billiards.[65 ] 
 Washington 's stepdaughter [REDACTED] suffered from epileptic attacks from age 12 , and she died in his arms in 1773 . The following day , he wrote to [REDACTED] [REDACTED] : " It is easier to conceive , than to describe , the distress of this Family".[66 ] He canceled all business activity and remained with [REDACTED] every night for three months.[67 ] 
 Washington played a central role before and during the American Revolution . His distrust of the British military had begun when he was passed over for promotion into the Regular Army . Opposed to taxes imposed by the British Parliament on the Colonies without proper representation,[68 ] he and other colonists were also angered by the Royal Proclamation of 1763 which banned American settlement west of the Allegheny Mountains and protected the British fur trade.[69 ] 
 Washington believed the Stamp Act 1765 was an " Act of Oppression " and celebrated its repeal the following year.[f ] In March 1766 , Parliament passed the Declaratory Act asserting that Parliamentary law superseded colonial law.[71 ] In the late 1760s , the interference of the British Crown in American lucrative western land speculation spurred the American Revolution.[72 ] Washington was a prosperous land speculator , and in 1767 , he encouraged " adventures " to acquire backcountry western lands.[72 ] Washington helped lead widespread protests against the Townshend Acts passed by Parliament in 1767 , and he introduced a proposal in May 1769 which urged Virginians to boycott British goods ; the Acts were mostly repealed in 1770.[73 ] 
 Parliament sought to punish Massachusetts colonists for their role in the Boston Tea Party in 1774 by passing the Coercive Acts , which Washington saw as " an invasion of our rights and privileges".[74 ] He said Americans must not submit to acts of tyranny since " custom and use shall make us as tame and abject slaves , as the blacks we rule over with such arbitrary sway".[75 ] That July , he and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] drafted a list of resolutions for the Fairfax County committee , including a call to end the Atlantic slave trade , which were adopted.[76 ] 
 On August 1 , Washington attended the First Virginia Convention . There , he was selected as a delegate to the First Continental Congress.[77 ] As tensions rose in 1774 , he helped train militias in Virginia and organized enforcement of the Continental Association boycott of British goods instituted by the Congress.[78 ] 
 The American Revolutionary War broke out on April 19 , 1775 , with the Battles of Lexington and Concord and the Siege of Boston.[79 ] Upon hearing the news , Washington was " sobered and dismayed",[80 ] and he hastily departed Mount Vernon on May 4 , 1775 , to join the Second Continental Congress in Philadelphia.[81 ] 
 On June 14 , 1775 , Congress created the Continental Army and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] nominated Washington as its commander - in - chief , mainly because of his military experience and the belief that a Virginian would better unite the colonies . He was unanimously elected by Congress the next day.[82 ] Washington appeared before Congress in uniform and gave an acceptance speech on June 16 , declining a salary , though he was later reimbursed expenses.[83 ] 
 Washington was commissioned on June 19 and officially appointed by Congress as " General & Commander in chief of the army of the United Colonies and of all the forces raised or to be raised by them".[84 ] He was instructed to take charge of the Siege of Boston on June 22 , 1775.[85 ] 
 Congress chose his primary staff officers , including Major General [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , Adjutant General [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , Major General [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , Major General [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , and Major General [REDACTED] [REDACTED] . [ 86 ] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , a young bookkeeper , impressed Adams and Washington with ordnance knowledge and was subsequently promoted to colonel and chief of artillery . Similarly , Washington was impressed by [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] intelligence and bravery . He would later promote him to colonel and appoint him his aide - de - camp.[87 ] 
 Washington initially banned the enlistment of blacks , both free and enslaved , into the Continental Army . The British saw an opportunity to divide the colonies , and the colonial governor of Virginia issued a proclamation , which promised freedom to slaves if they joined the British.[88 ] Desperate for manpower by late 1777 , Washington relented and overturned his ban.[89 ] By the end of the war , around one - tenth of Washington 's army were blacks.[90 ] Following the British surrender , Washington sought to enforce terms of the preliminary Treaty of Paris ( 1783 ) by reclaiming slaves freed by the British and returning them to servitude . He arranged to make this request to Sir [REDACTED] [REDACTED] on May 6 , 1783 . Instead , [REDACTED] issued 3,000 freedom certificates and all former slaves in New York City were able to leave before the city was evacuated by the British in late November 1783.[91 ] 
 Early in 1775 , in response to the growing rebellious movement , London sent British troops to occupy Boston , led by General [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , commander of British forces in America.[92 ] They set up fortifications , making the city impervious to attack . Local militias surrounded the city and effectively trapped the British troops , resulting in a standoff.[93 ] 
 As Washington headed for Boston , word of his march preceded him , and he was greeted everywhere ; gradually , he became a symbol of the Patriot cause.[94 ] Upon arrival on July 2 , 1775 , two weeks after the Battle of Bunker Hill , he set up headquarters in Cambridge . When he went to inspect the army , he found undisciplined militia.[95 ] After consultation , he initiated [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] suggested reforms : drilling the soldiers and imposing strict discipline.[96 ] Washington ordered his officers to identify the skills of recruits to ensure military effectiveness , while removing incompetent officers.[97 ] He petitioned Gage , his former superior , to release captured Patriot officers from prison and treat them humanely.[98 ] In October 1775 , King [REDACTED] [REDACTED] declared that the colonies were in open rebellion and relieved Gage of command for incompetence , replacing him with General [REDACTED] [REDACTED] ] 
 The Continental Army , reduced to only 9,600 men by January 1776 due to expiring short - term enlistments , had to be supplemented with militia . Soon , they were joined by Knox with heavy artillery captured from Fort Ticonderoga.[100 ] When the Charles River froze over , Washington was eager to cross and storm Boston , but General [REDACTED] and others were opposed to untrained militia striking well - garrisoned fortifications . Instead , he agreed to secure the Dorchester Heights , 100 feet above Boston , with Knox 's artillery to try to force the British out.[101 ] 
 On March 9 , under cover of darkness , Washington 's troops bombarded British ships in Boston harbor . On March 17 , 9,000 British troops and Loyalists began a chaotic ten - day evacuation aboard 120 ships . Soon after , Washington entered the city with 500 men , with explicit orders not to plunder the city.[102 ] He refrained from exerting military authority in Boston , leaving civilian matters in the hands of local authorities.[g][104 ] 
 After the victory at Boston , Washington correctly guessed that the British would return to New York City , a Loyalist stronghold , and retaliate . He arrived there on April 13 , 1776 , and ordered the construction of fortifications to thwart the expected British attack . He also ordered his occupying forces to treat civilians and their property with respect , to avoid the abuses Bostonians suffered at the hands of British troops.[105 ] 
 Howe transported his resupplied army , with the British fleet , from Halifax to New York City .
