In 1796 DATE , Washington GPE declined to run for a third ORDINAL term of office.[315 ] In May 1792 DATE , in anticipation of his retirement , Washington GPE instructed [REDACTED] [REDACTED] to prepare a " valedictory address " , an initial draft of which was entitled the " Farewell Address".[316 ] In May 1796 DATE , Washington GPE sent the manuscript to [REDACTED] [REDACTED] who did an extensive rewrite , while Washington GPE provided final edits.[317 ] On September 19 , 1796 DATE , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] American Daily Advertiser ORG published the final version.[318 ]
Washington GPE stressed that national identity was paramount , as a united America GPE would safeguard freedom and prosperity . He warned the nation of three CARDINAL eminent dangers : regionalism , partisanship , and foreign entanglements , and said the " name of AMERICAN ORG , which belongs to you , in your national capacity , must always exalt the just pride of patriotism".[319 ] Washington GPE called for men to move beyond partisanship for the common good , stressing that the United States GPE must concentrate on its own interests . He warned against foreign alliances and their influence in domestic affairs , and bitter partisanship and the dangers of political parties.[320 ] He counseled friendship and commerce with all nations , but advised against involvement in European NORP wars.[321 ] He stressed the importance of religion , asserting that " religion and morality are indispensable supports " in a republic.[322 NORP ] Washington GPE 's address favored [REDACTED] 's Federalist NORP ideology and economic policies.[323 ]
He closed the address by reflecting on his legacy :
Though in reviewing the incidents of my Administration I am unconscious of intentional error , I am nevertheless too sensible of my defects not to think it probable that I may have committed many errors . Whatever they may be , I fervently beseech the Almighty to avert or mitigate the evils to which they may tend . I shall also carry with me the hope that my country will never cease to view them with indulgence , and that , after forty - five years DATE of my life dedicated to its service with an upright zeal , the faults of incompetent abilities will be consigned to oblivion , as myself must soon be to the mansions of rest.[324]After initial publication , many Republicans NORP , including [REDACTED] , criticized the Address ORG and described it as an anti - French NORP campaign document , with [REDACTED] believing that Washington GPE was strongly pro - British.[325 ]
In 1839 DATE , Washington GPE biographer Jared Sparks ORG maintained that Washington GPE 's " Farewell Address WORK_OF_ART was printed and published with the laws , by order of the legislatures , as an evidence of the value they attached to its political precepts , and of their affection for its author . "[ 326 CARDINAL ] In 1972 DATE , Washington GPE scholar [REDACTED] [REDACTED] referred to the Farewell Address ORG as receiving as much acclaim as [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] Declaration of Independence and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] Gettysburg Address.[327 ] In 2010 DATE , historian [REDACTED] [REDACTED] called the Farewell Address LAW one of the most influential statements on republicanism.[328 ]
Washington GPE retired to Mount Vernon GPE in March 1797 DATE and devoted time to his plantations and other business interests.[329 ] His plantation operations were only minimally profitable,[31 ] and his lands in the west ( Piedmont GPE ) were under Indian NORP attacks and yielded little income , with squatters there refusing to pay rent . He attempted to sell these but without success.[330 ] He became an even more committed Federalist NORP . He vocally supported the Alien and Sedition Acts and convinced Federalist [REDACTED] [REDACTED] to run for Congress ORG to weaken the Jeffersonian NORP hold on Virginia.[331 ]
Washington GPE grew restless in retirement , prompted by tensions with France GPE ; in a continuation of the French Revolutionary Wars ORG , French NORP privateers began seizing American NORP ships in 1798 DATE , and relations deteriorated with France GPE and led to the " Quasi - War WORK_OF_ART " . Washington GPE wrote to Secretary of War [REDACTED] [REDACTED] offering to organize President [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] Adams nominated him for a lieutenant general commission on July 4 , 1798 DATE , and the position of commander - in - chief of the armies.[333 ] Washington GPE served as the commanding general from July 13 , 1798 DATE , until his death 17 months DATE later.[334 ] He participated in planning for a provisional army , but avoided involvement in details . In advising McHenry ORG of potential officers for the army , he appeared to make a complete break with Jefferson 's ORG Democratic - Republicans NORP : " you could as soon scrub the blackamoor white , as to change the principles of a profest Democrat NORP ; and that he will leave nothing unattempted to overturn the government of this country . "[ 335 CARDINAL ] Washington GPE delegated the active leadership of the army to [REDACTED] , a major general . No army invaded the United States GPE during this period , and Washington GPE did not assume a field command.[336 ]
Washington GPE was known to be rich because of the well - known " glorified facade of wealth and grandeur " at Mount Vernon,[337 GPE ] but nearly all his wealth was in the form of land and slaves rather than ready cash . To supplement his income , he erected a distillery for substantial whiskey production.[338 ] He bought land parcels to spur development around the new Federal City ORG named in his honor , and he sold individual lots to middle - income investors rather than multiple lots to large investors , believing they would more likely commit to making improvements.[339 ]
On December 12 , 1799 DATE , Washington GPE inspected his farms on horseback . He returned home late and had guests for dinner . He had a sore throat the next day DATE but was well enough to mark trees for cutting . That evening TIME , Washington GPE complained of chest congestion.[340 ] The next morning , however , he awoke to an inflamed throat and difficulty breathing . He ordered estate overseer [REDACTED] [REDACTED] to remove nearly a pint of his blood ; bloodletting was a common practice of the time . His family summoned doctors [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] ] A fourth ORDINAL doctor , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , arrived some hours TIME after Washington GPE died.[342 ]
[REDACTED] initially believed Washington GPE had quinsy ; [REDACTED] thought the condition was a more serious " violent inflammation of the throat".[343 ] They continued the process of bloodletting to approximately five CARDINAL pints , but Washington GPE 's condition deteriorated further . [REDACTED] proposed a tracheotomy , but the other physicians were not familiar with that procedure and disapproved.[344 ORG ] Washington GPE instructed [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] to leave the room , while he assured Craik ORG , " Doctor , I die hard , but I am not afraid to go . "[ 345 CARDINAL ]
Washington GPE 's death came more swiftly than expected.[346 ] On his deathbed , out of fear of being entombed alive , he instructed his private secretary [REDACTED] [REDACTED] to wait three days DATE before his burial.[347 ] According to Lear GPE , Washington GPE died between 10 p.m. and 11 p.m. TIME on December 14 , 1799 DATE , with [REDACTED] seated at the foot of his bed . His last words were " ' Tis well " , from his conversation with [REDACTED] about his burial . He was 67.[348 CARDINAL ]
Congress ORG immediately adjourned for the day DATE upon news of Washington GPE 's death , and the Speaker 's chair was shroud in black the next morning.[349 ] The funeral was held four days DATE after his death on December 18 , 1799 DATE , at Mount Vernon GPE , where his body was interred . Cavalry and foot soldiers led the procession , and six CARDINAL colonels served as the pallbearers . The Mount Vernon funeral service was restricted mostly to family and friends.[350 ] Reverend [REDACTED] [REDACTED] read the funeral service by the vault with a brief address , followed by a ceremony performed by members of Washington GPE 's Masonic ORG lodge in Alexandria GPE , Virginia.[351 ] Word of his death traveled slowly ; church bells rang in the cities , and many businesses closed.[352 ] Memorial processions were held in major cities of the United States GPE . [REDACTED] wore a black mourning cape for one year DATE , and she burned their correspondence to protect their privacy . Only five CARDINAL letters between the couple are known to have survived : two CARDINAL from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] and three CARDINAL from him to her.[353 ]
The diagnosis of Washington GPE 's illness and the immediate cause of his death have been subjects of debate since his death . The published account of doctors Craik ORG and [REDACTED] stated that his symptoms were consistent with cynanche trachealis , a term then used to describe severe inflammation of the upper windpipe , including quinsy.[l ] Accusations have persisted since Washington GPE 's death concerning medical malpractice.[344 ] Modern medical authors have concluded that he likely died from severe epiglottitis complicated by the treatments , including multiple doses of calomel , a purgative , and extensive bloodletting which almost certainly caused hypovolemic shock.[m ]
Washington GPE was buried in the old Washington GPE family vault at Mount Vernon LOC . At the time of his death , his estate was worth an estimated $ 780,000 MONEY in 1799 DATE , equivalent to $ 13.72 million MONEY in 2022.[359 CARDINAL ] Washington GPE 's peak net worth was $ 587 million MONEY , including 300 CARDINAL slaves.[360 ] Washington GPE held title to more than 65,000 acres QUANTITY of land in 37 CARDINAL different locations.[72 ]
In 1830 DATE , a disgruntled ex - employee of the estate attempted to steal what he thought was Washington GPE 's skull , prompting the construction of a more secure vault.[361 ] In his will , Washington GPE had left instructions for the construction of a new vault as the old family vault was crumbling and needed repair even before his death.[352 ] A new vault was constructed at Mount Vernon LOC the following year DATE to receive the remains of [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] and other relatives.[362 ]
In 1832 DATE , a joint Congressional NORP committee debated moving his body from Mount Vernon LOC to a crypt in the Capitol FAC . The crypt had been built by architect [REDACTED] [REDACTED] in the 1820s DATE during the reconstruction of the burned - out capital , after the Burning of Washington FAC by the British NORP during the War of 1812 EVENT . Southern NORP opposition was intense , antagonized by an ever - growing rift between North GPE and South LOC ; many were concerned that Washington GPE 's remains could end up on " a shore foreign to his native soil " if the country became divided , and Washington GPE 's remains stayed in Mount Vernon.[363 ] LOC
On October 7 , 1837 DATE , Washington GPE 's remains , still in the original lead coffin , were placed within a marble sarcophagus designed by [REDACTED] [REDACTED] and constructed by [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] The sarcophagus was sealed and encased with planks , and an outer vault was constructed around it.[365 ] The outer vault has the sarcophagi of both [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] ; the inner vault has the remains of other Washington GPE family members and relatives.[362 ]
Washington GPE was somewhat reserved in personality , but was known for having a strong presence . He made speeches and announcements when required , but he was not a noted orator or debater.[366 ] He was taller than most of his contemporaries;[367 ] accounts of his height vary from 6 ft ( QUANTITY 1.83 CARDINAL m ) to 6 CARDINAL ft 3.5 CARDINAL in ( 1.92 CARDINAL m ) tall,[64][368 ] he weighed between 210220 pounds QUANTITY ( 95100 kg QUANTITY ) as an adult,[369 ] and was known for his great strength.[370 ]
He had grey - blue eyes and long reddish - brown hair . He did not wear a powdered wig ; instead he wore his hair curled , powdered , and tied in a queue in the fashion of the day.[371][372 ]
Washington GPE frequently suffered from severe tooth decay and ultimately lost all his teeth but one . He had several sets of false teeth during his presidency . Contrary to common lore , these were not made of wood , but of metal , ivory , bone , animal teeth , and human teeth possibly obtained from slaves.[373 ] These dental problems left him in constant pain , which he treated with laudanum.[374 ]
Washington GPE was a talented equestrian , with [REDACTED] [REDACTED] describing him as " the best horseman of his age".[375 ] He collected thoroughbreds at Mount Vernon LOC , his two CARDINAL favorite horses being [REDACTED] and Nelson.[376 ] He enjoyed hunting foxes , deer , ducks , and other game.[377 ] He was an excellent dancer and frequently attended the theater . He drank alcohol in moderation but was morally opposed to excessive drinking , smoking tobacco , gambling , and profanity.[378 ]
Washington GPE was descended from Anglican NORP minister [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , whose troubles with the Church of England ORG may have prompted his heirs to emigrate to America.[379 ] He was baptized as an infant in April 1732 DATE and became a devoted member of the Anglican NORP Church.[380 ] He served more than 20 years DATE as a vestryman and churchwarden at Fairfax GPE Parish NORP and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] in Virginia.[381 ] He privately prayed and read the Bible WORK_OF_ART daily DATE , and publicly encouraged people and the nation to pray.[382 ] He may have taken communion on a regular basis prior to the Revolution EVENT , but he did not do so following the war.[383 ]
Washington GPE believed in a " wise , inscrutable , and irresistible " Creator God who was active in the Universe ORG , contrary to deistic thought.[379 ] He referred to God in Enlightenment terms , including [REDACTED] , the Creator , or the Almighty , and the Divine Author or Supreme ORG Being.[384 ] He believed in a divine power who watched over battlefields , was involved in the outcome of war , protected his life , and was involved in American NORP politics and specifically the creation of the United States.[n][386 ] Historian [REDACTED] [REDACTED] has argued that Washington GPE avoided evangelistic Christianity NORP or hellfire - and - brimstone speech along with communion or anything inclined to " flaunt his religiosity " , saying that he " never used his religion as a device for partisan purposes or in official undertakings".[387 ] No mention of [REDACTED] [REDACTED] appears in his private correspondence , and such references are rare in his public writings.[388 ] At the same time , Washington GPE frequently quoted from the Bible WORK_OF_ART or paraphrased it , and often referred to the Anglican Book of Common Prayer.[389 ] ORG Washington GPE emphasized religious toleration in a nation with numerous denominations and religions . He publicly attended services of different Christian NORP denominations and prohibited anti - Catholic NORP celebrations in the Army.[390 ] He engaged workers at Mount Vernon LOC without regard for religious belief or affiliation . While president , he acknowledged major religious sects and gave speeches on religious toleration.[391 ] He was distinctly rooted in the ideas , values , and modes of thinking of the Enlightenment,[392 ] but he harbored no contempt of organized Christianity NORP and its clergy , " being no bigot myself to any mode of worship".[392 ] In 1793 DATE , speaking to members of the New Church ORG in Baltimore GPE , Washington GPE said , " We have abundant reason to rejoice that in this Land the light of truth and reason has triumphed over the power of bigotry and superstition . "[ 393 CARDINAL ]
Freemasonry was a widely accepted institution in the late 18th century DATE , known for advocating moral teachings.[394 ] Washington GPE was attracted to the Masons ORG ' dedication to the Enlightenment principles of rationality , reason , and brotherhood . American NORP Masonic lodges did not share the anti - clerical views of the controversial European NORP lodges.[395 ]
A Masonic lodge was established in Fredericksburg GPE , Virginia GPE in September 1752 DATE , and Washington GPE was initiated two months later DATE at the age of 20 DATE as one of its first Entered Apprentices ORG . Within a year DATE , he progressed through its ranks to become a Master Mason.[396 ] Washington GPE had high regard for the Masonic Order ORG , but his lodge attendance was sporadic . In 1777 DATE , a convention of Virginia GPE lodges asked him to be the Grand Master of the newly established Grand Lodge FAC of Virginia GPE , but he declined due to his commitments leading the Continental Army ORG . After 1782 DATE , he frequently corresponded with Masonic NORP lodges and members,[397 ] and he was listed as Master in the Virginia GPE charter of [REDACTED] [REDACTED] No . 22 CARDINAL in 1788.[398 ]
In Washington GPE 's lifetime , slavery was deeply ingrained in the economic and social fabric of the Colony of Virginia GPE , which continued after the Revolution EVENT and the establishment of Virginia GPE as a state.[399][400 ] Slavery was legal in all of the Thirteen CARDINAL Colonies ORG prior to the American NORP Revolution.[401 ]
Washington GPE owned and rented enslaved African Americans NORP , and during his lifetime over 577 slaves lived and worked at Mount Vernon.[402][403 LOC ] He acquired them through inheritance , gaining control of 84 CARDINAL dower slaves upon his marriage to [REDACTED] , and purchased at least 71 CARDINAL slaves between 1752 DATE and 1773.[404 CARDINAL ] From 1786 DATE , he rented slaves ; at the time of his death he was renting 41.[405][402 CARDINAL ]
Prior to the Revolutionary War EVENT , Washington GPE 's view on slavery was the same as most Virginia GPE planters of the time.[406 ] Beginning in the 1760s DATE , however , Washington GPE gradually grew to oppose it . His first ORDINAL doubts were prompted by his transition from tobacco to grain crops , which left him with a costly surplus of slaves , causing him to question the system 's economic efficiency.[407 ] His growing disillusionment with the institution was spurred by the principles of the Revolution EVENT and revolutionary friends such as Lafayette ORG and Hamilton.[408 ] Most historians agree the Revolution EVENT was central to the evolution of Washington GPE 's attitudes on slavery;[409 ] " After 1783 DATE , " [REDACTED] [REDACTED] writes , " ... [ Washington GPE ] began to express inner tensions about the problem of slavery more frequently , though always in private".[410 ] Regardless , Washington GPE would remain dependent on slave labor to work his farms.[411 ]
The many contemporary reports of slave treatment at Mount Vernon LOC are varied and conflicting.[412 ] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] maintains that Washington GPE was frugal on spending for clothes and bedding for his slaves , and only provided them with just enough food , and that he maintained strict control over his slaves , instructing his overseers to keep them working hard from dawn to dusk year - round.[413 DATE ] In contrast , historian [REDACTED] [REDACTED] said : " Food , clothing , and housing seem to have been at least adequate".[414 ]
Washington GPE faced growing debts involved with the costs of supporting slaves . He held an " engrained sense of racial superiority " towards African Americans NORP but harbored no ill feelings toward them.[415 ] Some enslaved families worked at different locations on the plantation but were allowed to visit one another on their days off.[416 ] Washington GPE 's slaves received two hours TIME off for meals during the workday and were given time off on Sundays DATE and religious holidays.[417][418 ]
Some accounts report that Washington GPE opposed flogging but at times sanctioned its use , generally as a last resort , on both men and women slaves.[419 ] Washington GPE used both reward and punishment to encourage discipline and productivity in his slaves . He tried appealing to an individual 's sense of pride , gave better blankets and clothing to the " most deserving " , and motivated his slaves with cash rewards . He believed " watchfulness and admonition " were better deterrents against transgressions but would punish those who " will not do their duty by fair means " . Punishment ranged in severity from demotion back to fieldwork , through whipping and beatings , to permanent separation from friends and family by sale . Historian [REDACTED] [REDACTED] maintains that overseers were required to warn slaves before resorting to the lash and required Washington GPE 's written permission before whipping , though his extended absences did not always permit this.[420 ]
During his presidency , Washington GPE brought several of his slaves to the federal capital . When the capital moved from New York City GPE to Philadelphia GPE in 1791 DATE , the president began rotating his slave household staff periodically between the capital and Mount Vernon LOC . This was done deliberately to circumvent Pennsylvania GPE 's Slavery Abolition Act ORG , which stated that any slave who lived there for more than six months DATE was automatically freed.[421 ]
In May 1796 DATE , [REDACTED] 's personal and favorite slave Ona Judge escaped to Portsmouth ORG , New Hampshire GPE . At [REDACTED] 's behest , Washington GPE attempted to capture [REDACTED] , using a Treasury ORG agent , but failed . In February 1797 DATE , around the time of his 65th ORDINAL birthday , Washington GPE 's personal slave [REDACTED] [REDACTED] escaped from Mount Vernon GPE to Philadelphia GPE and was never found.[422 ]
In February 1786 DATE , Washington GPE took a census of Mount Vernon GPE and recorded 224 CARDINAL slaves.[423 ] By 1799 DATE , the slave population at Mount Vernon LOC totaled 317 CARDINAL , including 143 CARDINAL [REDACTED] ] Washington GPE owned 124 CARDINAL slaves , leased 40 CARDINAL , and held 153 CARDINAL for his wife 's dower interest.[425][6 ] Washington GPE supported many slaves who were too young or too old to work , greatly increasing Mount Vernon 's LOC slave population and causing the plantation to operate at a loss.[426 ]
Based on his private papers and on accounts from his contemporaries , Washington GPE slowly developed a cautious sympathy toward abolitionism that eventually ended with his will freeing his long - time valet [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , and then subsequently freeing the rest of his personally owned slaves outright upon [REDACTED] 's death.[427][428 ] As president , he remained publicly silent on the topic of slavery , believing it was a nationally divisive issue that could undermine the union.[429 ]
During the Revolutionary War EVENT , Washington GPE 's views on slavery began to change.[401 ] In a 1778 DATE letter to Lund Washington GPE , he made clear his desire " to get quit of Negroes ORG " when discussing the exchange of slaves for the land he wanted to [REDACTED] ] The next year DATE , Washington GPE stated his intention not to separate enslaved families as a result of " a change of masters".[431 ] During the 1780s DATE , Washington GPE privately expressed his support for gradual emancipation.[432 ] In the 1780s DATE , he gave moral support to a plan proposed by Lafayette ORG to purchase land and free slaves to work on it , but declined to participate in the experiment.[414 ]
Washington GPE privately expressed support for emancipation to prominent Methodists Thomas Coke LOC and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] in 1785 DATE but declined to sign their petition.[433 ] In personal correspondence the next year DATE , he made clear his desire to see the institution of slavery ended by a gradual legislative process , a view that correlated with the mainstream antislavery literature published in the 1780s DATE that Washington GPE possessed.[434 ] He significantly reduced his purchases of slaves after the war but continued to acquire them in small numbers.[435 ]
In 1788 DATE , Washington GPE declined a suggestion from a leading French NORP abolitionist , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , to establish an abolitionist society in Virginia GPE , stating that although he supported the idea , the time was not yet right.[436 ] Historian [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] wrote that Washington GPE was determined not to risk national unity.[437 ] Washington GPE never responded to any of the antislavery petitions he received , and the subject was not mentioned in either his last address to Congress ORG or his Farewell Address.[438 ]
The first ORDINAL clear indication that Washington GPE seriously intended to free his slaves appears in a letter written to his secretary , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , in 1794.[439 CARDINAL ] Washington GPE instructed Lear to find buyers for his land in western Virginia GPE , explaining in a private coda that he was doing so " to liberate a certain species of property which I possess , very repugnantly to my own feelings".[440 ] The plan , along with others Washington GPE considered in 1795 DATE and 1796 DATE , could not be realized because he failed to find buyers for his land , his reluctance to break up slave families , and the refusal of the Custis PRODUCT heirs to help prevent such separations by freeing their dower slaves at the same time.[441 ]
On July 9 , 1799 DATE , Washington GPE finished making his last will ; the longest provision concerned slavery . All his slaves were to be freed after the death of his wife . Washington ORG said he did not free them immediately because his slaves intermarried with his wife 's dower slaves . He forbade their sale or transportation out of Virginia GPE . The provision also provided that old and young freed people be taken care of indefinitely ; younger ones were to be taught to read and write and placed in suitable [REDACTED] [REDACTED] Washington GPE emancipated 123 CARDINAL slaves , one CARDINAL of the few large slave - holding Virginians NORP during the Revolutionary Era ORG to do so.[443][444 ]
On January 1 , 1801 DATE , one year DATE after [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] death , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] signed an order to free his slaves . Many of them , having never strayed far from Mount Vernon GPE , were reluctant to leave ; others refused to abandon spouses or children still held as dower slaves by the Custis PRODUCT estate and also stayed with or near Martha.[445 ] Following Washington GPE 's instructions in his will , funds were used to feed and clothe the young , aged , and infirm slaves until the early 1830s.[446 ]
Washington GPE 's legacy endures as one CARDINAL of the most influential in American NORP history since he served as commander - in - chief of the Continental Army ORG , a hero of the Revolution EVENT , and the first ORDINAL president of the United States GPE . Various historians maintain that he also was a dominant factor in America GPE 's founding.[447 ] Revolutionary War FAC comrade [REDACTED] [REDACTED] eulogized him as " First ORDINAL in war , first ORDINAL in peace , and first ORDINAL in the hearts of his countrymen".[448 ] [REDACTED] 's words became the hallmark by which Washington GPE 's reputation was impressed upon the American NORP memory , with some biographers regarding him as the great exemplar of republicanism . He set many precedents for the national government and the presidency in particular , and he was called the " Father of His Country WORK_OF_ART " as early as 1778.[o][450][451 ]
Washington GPE became an international symbol for liberation and nationalism as the leader of the first ORDINAL successful revolution against a colonial empire . The Federalists NORP made him the symbol of their party , but the Jeffersonians NORP continued to distrust his influence for years DATE and delayed building the Washington GPE Monument.[452 ] Washington GPE was elected a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences ORG on January 31 DATE , 1781.[453 CARDINAL ]
In 1879 DATE , Congress ORG proclaimed Washington GPE 's Birthday to be a federal holiday.[454 ] Through a congressional joint resolution Public Law 94 CARDINAL - 479 , passed on January 19 , 1976 DATE , with an effective appointment date of July 4 , 1976 DATE , he was posthumously appointed to the grade of General of the Armies of the United States ORG during the American Bicentennial EVENT . President [REDACTED] [REDACTED] stated that Washington GPE would " rank first ORDINAL among all officers of the Army ORG , past and present".[p][456 ] On March 13 , 1978 DATE , Washington GPE was militarily promoted to the rank of General of the Armies.[457 ]
In 1809 DATE , Mason Locke Weems ORG wrote a hagiographic biography to honor Washington.[458 ] Historian [REDACTED] [REDACTED] maintains that Weems ORG attempted to humanize Washington GPE , making him look less stern , and to inspire " patriotism and morality " and to foster " enduring myths " , such as Washington GPE 's refusal to lie about damaging his father 's cherry tree.[459][460 ] Weems ' accounts have never been proven or disproven.[461 ] Historian [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , however , maintains that Washington GPE remains the only founder and president ever to be referred to as " godlike " , and points out that his character has been the most scrutinized by historians.[462 ] Biographer [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] concluded , " The great big thing stamped across that man is character . " Expanding on [REDACTED] 's assessment , historian [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] defined Washington GPE 's character as " integrity , self - discipline , courage , absolute honesty , resolve , and decision , but also forbearance , decency , and respect for others".[463 ]
In the 21st century DATE , Washington GPE 's reputation has been critically scrutinized . Along with other Founding Fathers , he has been condemned for holding enslaved people . Though he expressed the desire to see the abolition of slavery come through legislation , he did not initiate or support any initiatives for bringing about its end . This has led to calls from some activists to remove his name from public buildings and his statue from public spaces.[464 ] Nonetheless , Washington GPE maintains his place among the highest - ranked U.S. GPE Presidents.[465 ]
Many places and monuments have been named in honor of Washington GPE , most notably Washington GPE , D.C. GPE , the capital of the United States GPE , and the state of Washington GPE , the only U.S. GPE state to be named after a president.[466 ]
On February 21 , 1885 DATE , the Washington Monument ORG was dedicated . The 555 - foot QUANTITY marble obelisk , which stands on the National Mall PRODUCT in Washington GPE , D.C. GPE , was built between 18481854 and 18791884 DATE and was the tallest structure in the world between 1884 DATE and 1889.[467 DATE ]
Washington GPE appears as one CARDINAL of four CARDINAL U.S. GPE presidents on the Shrine of Democracy WORK_OF_ART , a colossal statue by [REDACTED] [REDACTED] on Mount Rushmore LOC in South LOC Dakota.[468 ]
A number of secondary schools and universities are named in honor of Washington GPE , including George Washington University ORG and Washington University ORG in St. Louis.[469][470 ]
Washington GPE appears on contemporary U.S. GPE currency , including the one - dollar MONEY bill , the Presidential one - dollar MONEY coin and the quarter - dollar MONEY coin ( the Washington quarter DATE ) . Washington GPE and [REDACTED] [REDACTED] appeared on the nation 's first ORDINAL postage stamps in 1847 DATE . Washington GPE has since appeared on many postage issues , more than any other person.[471 ]
